units of its own"{{cite conference |url=https://www.hotchips.org/wp-content/uploads/hc_archives/hc28/HC28.23-Tuesday-Epub/HC28.23.90-High-Perform-Epub/HC28.23.930-X86-core-MikeClark-AMD-final_v2-28.pdf#page=7 |title=A New x86 Core Architecture for the Next Generation of Computing |author=Mike Clark |date=August 23, 2016 |publisher=AMD |conference=HotChips 28}} [https://images.anandtech.com/doci/10591/HC28.AMD.Mike%20Clark.final-page-007.jpg page 7] || 8 DP FLOPs/cycle: pair 2-wide FMA instructions || 16 SP FLOPs/cycle: pair 4-wide FMA instructions |- | Intel Atom (Bonnell, Saltwell, Silvermont and Goldmont) || 2 DP FLOPs/cycle: scalar SSE2 addition + scalar SSE2 multiplication every other cycle || 8 SP FLOPs/cycle: 4-wide SSE addition + 4-wide SSE multiplication every other cycle |- | AMD Bobcat || 2 DP FLOPs/cycle: scalar SSE2 addition + scalar SSE2 multiplication every other cycle || 4 SP FLOPs/cycle: 4-wide SSE addition every other cycle + 4-wide SSE multiplication every other cycle |- | AMD Jaguar || 4 DP FLOPs/cycle: 2-wide SSE2 addition + 2-wide SSE2 multiplication || 8 SP FLOPs/cycle: 8-wide AVX addition every other cycle + 8-wide AVX multiplication every other cycle |- | ARM Cortex-A7 || 1 FLOPs/cycle: scalar addition + scalar multiplication every other cycle || 8 SP FLOPs/cycle: 4-wide NEON addition every other cycle + 4-wide NEON multiplication every other cycle |- | ARM Cortex-A9 || 1 FLOPs/cycle: scalar addition + scalar multiplication every other cycle || 8 SP FLOPs/cycle: 4-wide NEON addition every other cycle + 4-wide NEON multiplication every other cycle |- | ARM Cortex-A15 || 1 DP FLOPs/cycle: scalar FMA or scalar multiply-add || 8 SP FLOPs/cycle: 4-wide NEONv2 FMA or 4-wide NEON multiply-add |- | ARM Cortex-A32 || 2 DP FLOPs/cycle: scalar FMA or scalar multiply-add || 8 SP FLOPs/cycle: 4-wide NEONv2 FMA or 4-wide NEON multiply-add |- | ARM Cortex-A35 || 2 DP FLOPs/cycle: scalar FMA or scalar multiply-add || 8 SP FLOPs/cycle: 4-wide NEONv2 FMA or 4-wide NEON multiply-add |- | [[ARM Cortex-A53]] || 2 DP FLOPs/cycle: scalar FMA or scalar multiply-add || 8 SP FLOPs/cycle: 4-wide NEONv2 FMA or 4-wide NEON multiply-add |- | [[ARM Cortex-A57]] || 4 DP FLOPs/cycle: two scalar FMA or one 2-wide FMA || 8 SP FLOPs/cycle: 4-wide NEONv2 FMA or 4-wide NEON multiply-add |- | ARM Cortex-A72 || 2 DP FLOPs/cycle: scalar FMA or scalar multiply-add || 8 SP FLOPs/cycle: 4-wide NEONv2 FMA or 4-wide NEON multiply-add |- | Qualcomm Krait || 1 DP FLOPs/cycle: scalar FMA or scalar multiply-add || 8 SP FLOPs/cycle: 4-wide NEONv2 FMA or 4-wide NEON multiply-add |- | Qualcomm Kryo || 2 DP FLOPs/cycle: scalar FMA or scalar multiply-add || 8 SP FLOPs/cycle: 4-wide NEONv2 FMA or 4-wide NEON multiply-add |- | IBM PowerPC A2 (Blue Gene/Q), per core || colspan="2" | 8 DP FLOPs/cycle: 4-wide QPX FMA every cycle (SP elements are extended to DP and processed on the same units) |- | IBM PowerPC A2 (Blue Gene/Q), per thread || colspan="2" | 4 DP FLOPs/cycle: 4-wide QPX FMA every other cycle (SP elements are extended to DP and processed on the same units) |- | Intel [[Xeon Phi]] (Knights Corner), per core || 16 DP FLOPs/cycle: 8-wide FMA every cycle || 32 SP FLOPs/cycle: 16-wide FMA every cycle |- | Intel Xeon Phi (Knights Corner), per thread (two per core) || 8 DP FLOPs/cycle: 8-wide FMA every other cycle || 16 SP FLOPs/cycle: 16-wide FMA every other cycle |- | Intel Xeon Phi (Knights Landing) || 32 DP FLOPs/cycle: two 8-wide FMA instructions || 64 SP FLOPs/cycle: two 16-wide FMA instructions |- | Standard [[graphics processing unit|GPU]] || Different || 2 SP FLOPs/cycle |} ==Performance records== ===Single computer records=== In June 1997, [[Intel]]'s [[ASCI Red]] was the world's first computer to achieve one teraFLOPS and beyond. Sandia director Bill Camp said that ASCI Red had the best reliability of any supercomputer ever built, and "was supercomputing's high-water mark in longevity, price, and performance".{{cite web|title=Sandia's ASCI Red, world's first teraflop supercomputer, is decommissioned |url=http://www.jacobsequity.com/ASCI%20Red%20Supercomputer.pdf |accessdate=November 17, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101105131112/http://www.jacobsequity.com/ASCI%20Red%20Supercomputer.pdf |archivedate=November 5, 2010 }} [[NEC]]'s [[NEC SX-9|SX-9]] supercomputer was the world's first [[vector processor]] to exceed 100 gigaFLOPS per single core. For comparison, a [[calculator|handheld calculator]] performs relatively few FLOPS. A computer response time below 0.1 second in a calculation context is usually perceived as instantaneous by a human operator,{{cite web |url=http://www.useit.com/papers/responsetime.html |title=Response Times: The Three Important Limits |accessdate=June 11, 2008 |publisher=Jakob Nielsen}} so a simple calculator needs only about 10 FLOPS to be considered functional. In June 2006, a new computer was announced by Japanese research institute [[RIKEN]], the [[MDGRAPE-3]]. The computer's performance tops out at one petaFLOPS, almost two times faster than the Blue Gene/L, but MDGRAPE-3 is not a general purpose computer, which is why it does not appear in the [[TOP500|Top500.org]] list. It has special-purpose [[pipeline (computing)|pipelines]] for simulating molecular dynamics. By 2007, [[Intel|Intel Corporation]] unveiled the experimental [[multi-core]] [[Teraflops Research Chip|POLARIS]] chip, which achieves 1 teraFLOPS at 3.13 GHz. The 80-core chip can raise this result to 2 teraFLOPS at 6.26 GHz, although the thermal dissipation at this frequency exceeds 190 watts.{{cite web|author=Richard Swinburne |url=http://www.bit-tech.net/hardware/2007/04/30/the_arrival_of_teraflop_computing/2 |title=The Arrival of TeraFLOP Computing |publisher=bit-tech.net |date=April 30, 2007 |accessdate=February 9, 2012}} On June 26, 2007, [[IBM]] announced the second generation of its top supercomputer, dubbed Blue Gene/P and designed to continuously operate at speeds exceeding one petaFLOPS. When configured to do so, it can reach speeds in excess of three petaFLOPS.{{cite news|url=http://www.top500.org/lists/2008/06|title=June 2008|publisher=TOP500|accessdate=July 8, 2008}} In June 2007, Top500.org reported the fastest computer in the world to be the [[Blue Gene|IBM Blue Gene/L]] supercomputer, measuring a peak of 596 teraFLOPS.{{cite news|url=http://top500.org/news/2007/06/23/29th_top500_list_world_s_fastest_supercomputers_released |title=29th TOP500 List of World's Fastest Supercomputers Released |date=June 23, 2007 |publisher=Top500.org |accessdate=July 8, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509064814/http://www.top500.org/news/2007/06/23/29th_top500_list_world_s_fastest_supercomputers_released |archivedate=May 9, 2008 |df=mdy }} The [[Cray XT4]] hit second place with 101.7 teraFLOPS. On October 25, 2007, [[NEC]] Corporation of Japan issued a press release announcing its SX series model [[SX-9]],{{cite news|url=http://www.nec.co.jp/press/en/0710/2501.html|title=NEC Launches World's Fastest Vector Supercomputer, SX-9|date=October 25, 2007|publisher=NEC|accessdate=July 8, 2008}} claiming it to be the world's fastest vector supercomputer. The [[SX-9]] features the first CPU capable of a peak vector performance of 102.4 gigaFLOPS per single core. On February 4, 2008, the [[National Science Foundation|NSF]] and the [[University of Texas at Austin]] opened full scale research runs on an [[AMD]], [[Sun Microsystems|Sun]] supercomputer named [[Texas Advanced Computing Center#Ranger|Ranger]],{{cite web |url = http://www.tacc.utexas.edu/resources/hpcsystems/ |title = University of Texas at Austin, Texas Advanced Computing Center |accessdate = September 13, 2010 |quote = Any researcher at a U.S. institution can submit a proposal to request an allocation of cycles on the system. |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090801102108/http://www.tacc.utexas.edu/resources/hpcsystems/ |archivedate = August 1, 2009 |df = mdy }} the most powerful supercomputing system in the world for open science research, which operates at sustained speed of 0.5 petaFLOPS. On May 25, 2008, an American supercomputer built by [[IBM]], named '[[IBM Roadrunner|Roadrunner]]', reached the computing milestone of one petaFLOPS. It headed the June 2008 and November 2008 [[TOP500]] list of the most powerful supercomputers (excluding [[grid computing|grid computers]]).{{cite web |url=http://www.computerworld.com/action/article.do?command=viewArticleBasic&taxonomyName=hardware&articleId=9095318&taxonomyId=12&intsrc=kc_top |title=IBM's Roadrunner smashes 4-minute mile of supercomputing |accessdate=June 10, 2008 |author=Sharon Gaudin |date=June 9, 2008 |publisher=Computerworld |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081224001155/http://www.computerworld.com/action/article.do?command=viewArticleBasic&taxonomyName=hardware&articleId=9095318&taxonomyId=12&intsrc=kc_top |archivedate=December 24, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.top500.org/lists/2008/11/press-release |title=Austin ISC08 |publisher=Top500.org |date=November 14, 2008 |accessdate=February 9, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222023827/http://www.top500.org/lists/2008/11/press-release |archivedate=February 22, 2012 |df=mdy }} The computer is located at Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico. The computer's name refers to the New Mexico [[List of U.S. state birds|state bird]], the [[greater roadrunner]] (''Geococcyx californianus'').{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/7443557.stm|title=Supercomputer sets petaflop pace |last=Fildes|first=Jonathan |date=June 9, 2008|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=July 8, 2008}} In June 2008, AMD released ATI Radeon HD 4800 series, which are reported to be the first GPUs to achieve one teraFLOPS. On August 12, 2008, AMD released the ATI Radeon HD 4870X2 graphics card with two [[Radeon HD 4000 series|Radeon R770]] GPUs totaling 2.4 teraFLOPS. In November 2008, an upgrade to the Cray XT Jaguar supercomputer at the Department of Energy's (DOE's) Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) raised the system's computing power to a peak 1.64 petaFLOPS, making Jaguar the world's first petaFLOPS system dedicated to open research. In early 2009 the supercomputer was named after a mythical creature, [[Kraken]]. Kraken was declared the world's fastest university-managed supercomputer and sixth fastest overall in the 2009 TOP500 list. In 2010 Kraken was upgraded and can operate faster and is more powerful. In 2009, the [[Cray]] Jaguar performed at 1.75 petaFLOPS, beating the IBM Roadrunner for the number one spot on the TOP500 list.{{cite news| url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/11/15/supercomputer-ibm-jaguar-technology-cio-network-cray.html?feed=rss_popstories | work=Forbes | first=Andy | last=Greenberg | title=Cray Dethrones IBM In Supercomputing | date=November 16, 2009}} In October 2010, China unveiled the [[Tianhe-1]], a supercomputer that operates at a peak computing rate of 2.5 petaFLOPS.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-11644252 | work=BBC News | title=China claims supercomputer crown | date=October 28, 2010}}{{cite web|last=Dillow |first=Clay |url=http://www.popsci.com/technology/article/2010-10/china-unveils-2507-petaflop-supercomputer-worlds-fastest |title=China Unveils 2507 Petaflop Supercomputer, the World's Fastest |publisher=Popsci.com |date=October 28, 2010 |accessdate=February 9, 2012}} {{As of|2010}} the fastest six-core PC [[microprocessor|processor]] reaches 109 gigaFLOPS ([[Intel Core#Core i7|Intel Core i7]] [[Gulftown (microprocessor)|980 XE]]){{Cite web |url=http://techgage.com/article/intels_core_i7-980x_extreme_edition_-_ready_for_sick_scores/8 |title=Intel's Core i7-980X Extreme Edition – Ready for Sick Scores?: Mathematics: Sandra Arithmetic, Crypto, Microsoft Excel |website=Techgage |date=March 10, 2010 |accessdate=February 9, 2012}} in double precision calculations. [[Graphics processing unit|GPU]]s are considerably more powerful. For example, [[Nvidia Tesla]] C2050 GPU computing processors perform around 515 gigaFLOPS{{cite web|url=http://www.nvidia.com/object/product_tesla_C2050_C2070_us.html |title=NVIDIA Tesla Personal Supercomputer |publisher=Nvidia.com |date= |accessdate=February 9, 2012}} in double precision calculations, and the AMD FireStream 9270 peaks at 240 gigaFLOPS.{{cite web|url=https://www.amd.com/us/products/workstation/firestream/firestream-9270/pages/firestream-9270.aspx |title=AMD FireStream 9270 GPU Compute Accelerator |publisher=Amd.com |date= |accessdate=February 9, 2012}} In single precision performance, Nvidia Tesla C2050 computing processors perform around 1.03 teraFLOPS and the AMD FireStream 9270 cards peak at 1.2 teraFLOPS. Both Nvidia and AMD's consumer gaming GPUs may reach higher FLOPS. For example, AMD's HemlockXT 5970https://www.amd.com/us/products/desktop/graphics/ati-radeon-hd-5000/hd-5970/Pages/ati-radeon-hd-5970-specifications.aspx reaches 928 gigaFLOPS in double precision calculations with two GPUs on board and the Nvidia GTX 480 reaches 672 gigaFLOPS{{cite web|url=http://www.nvidia.com/object/product_geforce_gtx_480_us.html |title=GeForce GTX 480 |publisher=Nvidia.com |date=July 20, 2010 |accessdate=February 9, 2012}} with one GPU on board. On December 2, 2010, the US Air Force unveiled a defense supercomputer made up of 1,760 [[PlayStation 3]] consoles that can run 500 teraFLOPS.{{cite web|last=Dillow |first=Clay |url=http://www.popsci.com/technology/article/2010-12/air-forces-new-supercomputer-made-1760-playstation-3s |title=Air Force Unveils Fastest Defense Supercomputer, Made of 1760 PlayStation 3 |publisher=Popsci.com |date= |accessdate=February 9, 2012}} In November 2011, it was announced that Japan had achieved 10.51 petaFLOPS with its [[K computer]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fujitsu.com/global/news/pr/archives/month/2011/20111102-02.html |title='K computer' Achieves Goal of 10 Petaflops |publisher=Fujitsu.com |date= |accessdate=February 9, 2012}} It is still under development and software performance tuning is currently underway. It has 88,128 [[SPARC64 VIIIfx]] [[central processing unit|processor]]s in 864 racks, with theoretical performance of 11.28 petaFLOPS. It is named after the Japanese word "[[wikt:?#Japanese|kei]]", which stands for 10 [[1,000,000,000,000,000|quadrillion]],See [[Japanese numerals#Large numbers|Japanese numbers]] corresponding to the target speed of 10 petaFLOPS. On November 15, 2011, Intel demonstrated a single x86-based processor, code-named "Knights Corner", sustaining more than a teraFLOPS on a wide range of [[DGEMM]] operations. Intel emphasized during the demonstration that this was a sustained teraFLOPS (not "raw teraFLOPS" used by others to get higher but less meaningful numbers), and that it was the first general purpose processor to ever cross a teraFLOPS.{{cite web|url=http://www.tomshardware.com/news/intel-knights-corner-mic-co-processor,14002.html |title=Intel's Knights Corner: 50+ Core 22nm Co-processor|accessdate=November 16, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eetimes.com/electronics-news/4230654/Intel-unveils-1-TFLOP-s-Knight-s-Corner |title=Intel unveils 1 TFLOP/s Knight's Corner|accessdate=November 16, 2011}} On June 18, 2012, [[IBM Sequoia|IBM's Sequoia supercomputer system]], based at the U.S. Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL), reached 16 petaFLOPS, setting the world record and claiming first place in the latest TOP500 list.{{cite news|last=Clark|first=Don|title=IBM Computer Sets Speed Record|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303379204577472773983130902|accessdate=June 18, 2012|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=June 18, 2012}} On November 12, 2012, the TOP500 list certified [[Titan (supercomputer)|Titan]] as the world's fastest supercomputer per the LINPACK benchmark, at 17.59 petaFLOPS.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-20272810 |title=BBC News – US Titan supercomputer clocked as world's fastest |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=November 12, 2012 |accessdate=February 28, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://top500.org/blog/lists/2012/11/press-release/ |title=Oak Ridge Claims No. 1 Position on Latest TOP500 List with Titan | TOP500 Supercomputer Sites |publisher=Top500.org |date=November 12, 2012 |accessdate=February 28, 2013}} It was developed by Cray Inc. at the [[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]] and combines AMD Opteron processors with "Kepler" NVIDIA Tesla graphic processing unit (GPU) technologies.{{Cite web |last=Montalbano |first=Elizabeth |url=http://www.informationweek.com/news/government/enterprise-architecture/231900554 |title=Oak Ridge Labs Builds Fastest Supercomputer |website=Informationweek |date=October 11, 2011 |accessdate=February 9, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Tibken |first=Shara |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-11386_3-57541791-76/titan-supercomputer-debuts-for-open-scientific-research/ |title=Titan supercomputer debuts for open scientific research | Cutting Edge – CNET News |publisher=News.cnet.com |date=October 29, 2012 |accessdate=February 28, 2013}} On June 10, 2013, China's [[Tianhe-2]] was ranked the world's fastest with 33.86 petaFLOPS.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alexknapp/2013/06/17/chinese-supercomputer-is-now-the-worlds-fastest-by-a-lot/ |title=Chinese Supercomputer Is Now The World's Fastest – By A Lot|publisher=Forbes Magazine |date=June 17, 2013 |accessdate=June 17, 2013}} On June 20, 2016, China's [[Sunway TaihuLight]] was ranked the world's fastest with 93 petaFLOPS on the LINPACK benchmark (out of 125 peak petaFLOPS). The system, which is almost exclusively based on technology developed in China, is installed at the National Supercomputing Center in Wuxi, and represents more performance than the next five most powerful systems on the TOP500 list combined.{{cite web|last1=Feldman|first1=Michael|title=China Races Ahead in TOP500 Supercomputer List, Ending US Supremacy|url=https://www.top500.org/news/china-races-ahead-in-top500-supercomputer-list-ending-us-supremacy/|website=TOP500.org|accessdate=31 December 2016}} In June 2018, [[Summit (supercomputer)|Summit]], an IBM-built supercomputer now running at the Department of Energy’s (DOE) Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL), captured the number one spot with a performance of '''122.3 petaflops''' on High Performance Linpack (HPL), the benchmark used to rank the TOP500 list. Summit has 4,356 nodes, each one equipped with two 22-core Power9 CPUs, and six NVIDIA Tesla V100 GPUs.{{Cite web|url=https://www.top500.org/lists/2018/06/|title=June 2018 {{!}} TOP500 Supercomputer Sites|website=www.top500.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-17}} ===Distributed computing records=== [[Distributed computing]] uses the [[Internet]] to link [[personal computer]]s to achieve more FLOPS: * {{As of|2016|10}}, the [[Folding@home]] network has over 100 petaFLOPS of total computing power.{{cite web|url=https://folding.stanford.edu/home/closing-in-on-100-petaflops/ |title=Closing in on 100 Petaflops|date=May 11, 2016|publisher=Folding@Home|accessdate=July 17, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/main.py?qtype=osstats2 |title=Folding@home team stats pages |publisher=Folding@Home|accessdate=October 14, 2016}} It was the first computing project of any kind to cross the 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 native petaFLOPS milestones. This level of performance is primarily enabled by the cumulative effort of a vast array of powerful [[Graphics processing unit|GPU]] and [[Central processing unit|CPU]] units.{{cite press release |title = Sony Computer Entertainment's Support for Folding@home Project on PlayStation™3 Receives This Year's "Good Design Gold Award" |url = http://www.scei.co.jp/corporate/release/081106de.html |publisher = Sony Computer Entertainment Inc. |date = November 6, 2008 |accessdate = December 11, 2008 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090131082202/http://www.scei.co.jp/corporate/release/081106de.html |archivedate = January 31, 2009 |df = mdy }} * {{As of|2018|06}}, the entire [[BOINC]] network averages about 20 petaFLOPS.{{cite web |url=http://boinc.berkeley.edu/ |title=Computering Power |publisher=BOINC |accessdate=June 15, 2018}} * {{As of|2018|06}}, [[SETI@Home]], employing the [[BOINC]] software platform, averages 896 teraFLOPS.{{cite web |url=http://boincstats.com/en/stats/0/project/detail |title=SETI@Home Credit overview |publisher=BOINC |accessdate=June 15, 2018}} * {{As of|2018|06}}, [[Einstein@Home]], a project using the [[BOINC]] network, is crunching at 3 petaFLOPS.{{cite web |url=http://boincstats.com/en/stats/5/project/detail |title=Einstein@Home Credit overview |publisher=BOINC |accessdate=June 15, 2018}} * {{As of|2018|06}}, [[MilkyWay@Home]], using the [[BOINC]] infrastructure, computes at 847 teraFLOPS.{{cite web|url=http://boincstats.com/en/stats/61/project/detail|title=MilkyWay@Home Credit overview|publisher=BOINC|accessdate=June 15, 2018}} * {{As of|2018|06}}, [[Great Internet Mersenne Prime Search|GIMPS]], is searching for [[Mersenne prime]]s and sustaining 306 teraFLOPS.{{cite web |url=http://www.mersenne.org/primenet |title=Internet PrimeNet Server Distributed Computing Technology for the Great Internet Mersenne Prime Search |work=GIMPS |accessdate=June 15, 2018 |postscript= }} ===Future developments=== {{Further information|Exascale computing}} In 2008, [[James Bamford]]'s book ''[[The Shadow Factory]]'' reported that [[NSA]] told the [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]] it would need an exaflop computer by 2018.{{cite book |title=[[The Shadow Factory]] |author=James Bamford |author-link=James Bamford |publisher= [[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]] |year=2008 |page=339 |isbn=0-385-52132-4}} Given the current speed of progress, [[supercomputer]]s are projected to reach 1 exaFLOPS (EFLOPS) in 2018.http://singularityhub.com/2012/11/01/the-race-to-a-billion-billion-operations-per-second-an-exaflop-by-2018/ [[Cray, Inc.]] announced in December 2009 a plan to build a 1 EFLOPS supercomputer before 2020.{{cite web|url=http://eetimes.com/news/latest/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=222000288 |title=Cray studies exascale computing in Europe |publisher=Eetimes.com |date= |accessdate=February 9, 2012}} Erik P. DeBenedictis of [[Sandia National Laboratories]] theorizes that a zettaFLOPS (ZFLOPS) computer is required to accomplish full weather modeling of two week time span.{{cite book |chapter=Reversible logic for supercomputing |title=Proceedings of the 2nd conference on Computing frontiers |last=DeBenedictis |first=Erik P. |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2005 |publisher= ACM Press|location= New York, NY|isbn=1-59593-019-1 |pages=391–402 |chapterurl=http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1062325 }} Such systems might be built around 2030.{{cite news|first=|last=|authorlink=|coauthors=|title=IDF: Intel says Moore's Law holds until 2029|url=http://www.h-online.com/newsticker/news/item/IDF-Intel-says-Moore-s-Law-holds-until-2029-734779.html|work=Heise Online|publisher=|date=April 4, 2008|accessdate=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208075357/http://www.h-online.com/newsticker/news/item/IDF-Intel-says-Moore-s-Law-holds-until-2029-734779.html|archivedate=December 8, 2013|df=mdy-all}} ==Cost of computing== ===Hardware costs=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Approximate cost per GFLOPS ! Approximate cost per GFLOPS ({{Inflation-year|US}} US dollars){{Inflation-fn|US}} !'''Approximate cost per TFLOPS (2017 US dollars)''' ! Platform providing the lowest cost per GFLOPS ! Comments |- | 1961 | $18.7 billion | ${{Inflation|US|18.7|1961|r=1|fmt=c}} billion |${{Inflation|US|18.7|1961|r=1|fmt=c}} trillion | About 2400 [[IBM 7030 Stretch]] supercomputers costing $7.78 million each | The [[IBM 7030 Stretch]] performs one floating-point multiply every 2.4 microseconds.{{cite web|url=http://computer-history.info/Page4.dir/pages/IBM.7030.Stretch.dir/ |title=The IBM 7030 (STRETCH) |publisher=Norman Hardy |accessdate=February 24, 2017}} |- | 1984 | $18,750,000 | ${{Inflation|US|18750000|1984|r=-4|fmt=c}} |$44.2 billion | [[Cray X-MP]]/48 | $15,000,000 / 0.8 GFLOPS |- | 1997 | $30,000 | ${{Inflation|US|30000|1997|r=-3|fmt=c}} |$46,000,000 | Two 16-processor [[Beowulf (computing)|Beowulf]] clusters with [[Pentium Pro]] microprocessors{{cite web|url=http://loki-www.lanl.gov/papers/sc97/ |title=Loki and Hyglac |publisher=Loki-www.lanl.gov |date=July 13, 1997 |accessdate=February 9, 2012}} | |- | {{sort|2000/04|April 2000}} | $1,000 | ${{Inflation|US|1016|2000|r=-1|fmt=c}} |$1,440,000 | [[Beowulf (computing)|Bunyip Beowulf cluster]] | Bunyip was the first sub-US$1/MFLOPS computing technology. It won the Gordon Bell Prize in 2000. |- | {{sort|2000/05|May 2000}} | $640 | ${{Inflation|US|649|2000|fmt=c}} |$922,000 | [[Kentucky Linux Athlon Testbed|KLAT2]] | KLAT2 was the first computing technology which scaled to large applications while staying under US-$1/MFLOPS.{{Cite web |url=http://aggregate.org/KLAT2/ |title=Kentucky Linux Athlon Testbed 2 (KLAT2) |website=The Aggregate |date= |accessdate=February 9, 2012}} |- | {{sort|2003/08|August 2003}} | $82 | ${{Inflation|US|82|2003|fmt=c}} |$109,000 | KASY0 | KASY0 was the first sub-US$100/GFLOPS computing technology.{{Cite web |url=http://aggregate.org/KASY0/ |title=KASY0 |website=The Aggregate |date=August 22, 2003 |accessdate=February 9, 2012}} |- | {{sort|2007/08|August 2007}} | $48 | ${{Inflation|US|48|2007|fmt=c}} |$57,000 | Microwulf | As of August 2007, this 26.25 GFLOPS "personal" Beowulf cluster can be built for $1256.{{cite web|url=http://www.calvin.edu/~adams/research/microwulf/ |title=Microwulf: A Personal, Portable Beowulf Cluster |accessdate=February 9, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070912061302/http://www.calvin.edu/~adams/research/microwulf/ |archivedate=September 12, 2007 }} |- | {{sort|2011/03|March 2011}} | $1.80 | ${{Inflation|US|1.82|2011|r=2|fmt=c}} |$1,980 | HPU4Science | This $30,000 cluster was built using only commercially available "gamer" grade hardware.Adam Stevenson, Yann Le Du, and Mariem El Afrit. "[https://arstechnica.com/science/news/2011/03/high-performance-computing-on-gamer-pcs-part-1-hardware.ars High-performance computing on gamer PCs]." ''Ars Technica''. March 31, 2011. |- | {{sort|2012/08|August 2012}} | $0.75 | ${{Inflation|US|0.75|2012|r=2|fmt=c}} |$800 | Quad AMD Radeon 7970 GHz System | A quad [[AMD]] [[Radeon HD 7000 Series|Radeon 7970]] desktop computer reaching 16 TFLOPS of single-precision, 4 TFLOPS of double-precision computing performance. Total system cost was $3000; Built using only commercially available hardware.{{cite web |url=http://www.overclock3d.net/reviews/gpu_displays/hd7970_quadfire_eyefinity_review/12 |title=HD7970 Quadfire Eyefinity Review |date=January 9, 2012 |website=OC3D.net |author=Tom Logan}} |- | {{sort|2013/06|June 2013}} | $0.22 | ${{Inflation|US|0.22|2013|r=2|fmt=c}} |$230 | Sony PlayStation 4 | The Sony [[PlayStation 4]] is listed as having a peak performance of 1.84 TFLOPS, at a price of $400"[https://www.cnbc.com/id/100805004 Sony Sparks Price War With PS4 Priced at $399]." ''CNBC''. June 11, 2013. |- | {{sort|2013/11|November 2013}} | $0.16 | ${{Inflation|US|0.16|2013|r=2|fmt=c}} |$170 | AMD Sempron 145 & GeForce GTX 760 System | Built using commercially available parts, a system using one AMD [[Sempron]] 145 and three [[Nvidia]] [[GeForce 700 series|GeForce GTX 760]] reaches a total of 6.771 TFLOPS for a total cost of $1090.66.http://www.freezepage.com/1384601420XCIGYKCBKJ |- | {{sort|2013/12|December 2013}} | $0.12 | ${{Inflation|US|0.12|2013|r=2|fmt=c}} |$130 | Pentium G550 & Radeon R9 290 System | Built using commercially available parts. [[Intel]] [[Sandy Bridge|Pentium G550]] and AMD [[AMD Radeon Rx 200 series|Radeon R9 290]] tops out at 4.848 TFLOPS grand total of US$681.84.http://www.freezepage.com/1387480124PSLSILVCMJ |- | {{sort|2015/01|January 2015}} | $0.08 | ${{Inflation|US|0.08|2015|r=2|fmt=c}} |$80 | Celeron G1830 & Radeon R9 295X2 System | Built using commercially available parts. Intel [[Haswell (microarchitecture)|Celeron G1830]] and AMD [[AMD Radeon Rx 200 series|Radeon R9 295X2]] tops out at over 11.5 TFLOPS at a grand total of US$902.57.http://www.freezepage.com/1420850340WGSMHXRBLEhttp://www.tomshardware.com/reviews/radeon-r9-295x2-review-benchmark-performance,3799.html |- | {{sort|2017/07|June 2017}} | $0.06 | ${{Inflation|US|0.06|2017|r=2|fmt=c}} |$60 | AMD Ryzen 7 1700 & AMD Radeon Vega Frontier Edition | Built using commercially available parts. AMD Ryzen 7 1700 CPU combined with AMD Radeon Vega FE cards in CrossFire tops out at over 50 TFLOPS at just under {{USD|3,000}} for the complete system.{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/intuitionmachine/building-a-50-teraflops-amd-vega-deep-learning-box-for-under-3k-ebdd60d4a93c|title=Building a 50 Teraflops AMD Vega Deep Learning Box for Under $3K|last=Perez|first=Carol E.|date=July 13, 2017|work=Intuition Machine|access-date=July 26, 2017}} |- |October 2017 |$0.03 |${{Inflation|US|0.03|2017|r=2|fmt=c}} |$30 |Intel Celeron G3930 & AMD RX Vega 64 |Built using commercially available parts. Three [[AMD RX Vega series|AMD RX Vega 64]] graphics cards provide just over 75 TFLOPS half precision (38 TFLOPS SP or 2.6 TFLOPS DP when combined with the CPU) at ~$2,050 for the complete system.{{Cite web|url=https://pcpartpicker.com/user/mattebaughman/saved/8DQZ8d|title=lowest_$/fp16 - mattebaughman's Saved Part List - Celeron G3930 2.9GHz Dual-Core, Radeon RX VEGA 64 8GB (3-Way CrossFire), XON-350_BK ATX Mid Tower - PCPartPicker|website=pcpartpicker.com|access-date=2017-09-13}} |} ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=24em}} * [[FLOPS per watt]] * [[Gordon Bell Prize]] * [[Multiply–accumulate operation]] * [[LINPACK benchmarks]] * [[SPECfp]] * [[SPECint]] * [[SUPS]] * [[TOP500]] * [[Moore's law]] {{div col end}} {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= }} {{Graphics Processing Unit}} {{CPU technologies}} {{Portal bar|Computer Science}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Flops}} [[Category:Benchmarks (computing)]] [[Category:Floating point]] [[Category:Units of frequency]]

{{Infobox book | name = Fields Virology | title_orig = Virology | translator = | image = Fields Virology.jpg | caption = | author = [[Bernard N. Fields]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Virology]] | genre = | pub_date = 1985 | media_type = | pages = | isbn = 1451105630 | oclc = | preceded_by = Fields Virology 5th Edition ({{ISBN|0781760607}}) | followed_by = }} '''''Fields Virology''''' is an [[English language|English-language]] [[virology]] [[textbook]], published in two volumes, originally edited by [[Bernard N. Fields]]. The first edition in 1985 was called '''''Virology''''', but the book's title was changed from the second edition to ''Fields Virology''. The book is widely regarded as an influential work on the subject and is cited as the ''bible of virology'' by many virologists.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sgm.ac.uk/pubs/micro_today/book_reviews/MTNOV07/MTN07_01.cfm |title=Microbiology Today: Book Reviews: Fields Virology |author=Ulrich Desselberger |date= |work= |publisher=[[Society for General Microbiology]] |accessdate=22 October 2012}}</ref>
Fields was the senior editor for the first three editions.<ref>{{citation |title=In memoriam Bernard Nathan Fields |author=Anon. |journal=[[Archives of Virology]] |volume=140 |pages=983–85|year=1995 }}</ref> After his death in 1995, subsequent editions have retained his name in the title. The 6th edition came out in 2013, edited by [[David M. Knipe]] and [[Peter Howley]], and published by [[Wolters Kluwer]] under the [[Lippincott Williams & Wilkins]] imprint.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1985 books]] [[Category:Biology books]] [[Category:Medical manuals]]

{{notability|date=November 2018}} {{primary sources|date=November 2018}} {{Update|date=December 2017}} {{for|a general list of flags|Lists of flags}} {{Infobox Organization |name = Flags of the World |abbreviation = FOTW |image = Flag of FOTW.svg{{!}}border |size = 295px |caption = Official flag of FOTW |map = |msize = |mcaption = |motto = |formation = 1993 |extinction = |type = Noncommercial |location = |headquarters = Nominally [[Wolfville]], [[Nova Scotia]] |purpose = [[Vexillology|Vexillological]] |affiliations = [[International Federation of Vexillological Associations]] |membership = 1,126 {{cite web |title=Flags of the World mailing list |url=https://groups.yahoo.com/group/flags/ |work=[[Yahoo! Groups]] |accessdate=9 December 2012}} |language = English |leader_title = Listmaster |leader_name = Nathan Lamm |key_people = Rob Raeside, Editorial Director
Jan Mertens, Apprentice-Listmaster |num_staff = 21{{cite web |url=http://flagspot.net/flags/edistaff.html |title=FOTW Editorial Staff |website=Flags of the World |accessdate=5 June 2016}} |budget = |website = {{URL|http://www.flagspot.net/|www.FlagSpot.net}} }} '''Flags of the World''' (abbreviated '''FOTW''' or '''FotW''') is an [[Internet]]-based [[vexillological]] association and resource. Its principal project is the Internet's largest website devoted to [[vexillology]], containing comprehensive information about all kinds of [[flag]]s,{{cite web |url=http://fiav.org/current-members/ |title=Current Members |website=Fédération Internationale des Associations Vexillologiques |year=2016 |accessdate=5 June 2016}} and an associated [[Electronic mailing list|mailing list]]. The mailing list began as a discussion group in about September 1993, while the website was founded by Giuseppe Bottasini in late 1994, and Rob Raeside took over as director in 1998.{{cite web |url= http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/fotwhist.html |title=History of FOTW |website=Flags of the World |year=2015 |accessdate=5 June 2016}} Flags of the World became the 56th member of the [[International Federation of Vexillological Associations|FIAV]] in 2001. Flags of the World describes itself as "...an Internet group, the sole purpose of which is the advancement of the pursuit of vexillology, that is the creation and development of a body of knowledge about flags and flag usage of all types".''Flags of the World'' mailing list rules, Part 4, Article 1. Both the website and the mailing list operate in the [[English language]], though there are members from around the world and as such information from many languages is translated and included. The mailing list is monitored by the FOTW Listmaster, while work on the website is coordinated by the FOTW Editorial Director. == Website == An editorial staff of 21 unpaid volunteers{{cite web |url=http://flagspot.net/flags/edistaff.html |title=FOTW Editorial Staff |website=Flags of the World |accessdate=12 July 2009}} manages and edits the FOTW website, which (as of 2013) contains more than 53,000 pages about flags and more than 102,000 images of flags,{{cite web |url=http://flagspot.net/flags/ |title=Welcome to Flags of the World |website=Flags of the World |accessdate=12 July 2009}} and also includes an extensive online dictionary of [[vexillology]]. The website is updated once a week with fresh material; some [[mirror website|mirrors]] update monthly. Due to the high amount of material there is an editing backlog, causing some areas of FOTW to contain outdated information. There are also some mirrors that have not been updated for varying periods of time and which are therefore considered "historical". == Mailing list == The source for material on the FOTW website are contributions to the FOTW mailing list,{{cite web |url=https://groups.yahoo.com/group/flags/ |title=FOTW mailing list |website=Yahoo! Groups}} which has over 1,000 members, of which some 100 are active contributors. The mailing list has notable minorities of [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[French language|French]], [[Dutch language|Dutch]], and [[Russian language|Russian]] speakers. A staff of three unpaid volunteers manages and moderates the list. == Social media == An affiliated Flags of the World [[Facebook]] group has been established, inaugurated by Edward Mooney, Jr. {{as of|October 2018}} the group is run and moderated by a team of ten administrators, and has over 12,000 members throughout the world. == Graphical conventions == [[File:Color guide flags.svg|right|200px|thumb|FOTW Color Palette.]] FOTW displays standardized flag images in [[GIF]] format, usually at a height of 216 pixels. While the GIF file format is capable of displaying 256 colours, the site's standard calls for a more restricted "FOTW palette" of 32 colours.{{cite web |url=https://flagspot.net/flags/fotwcols.html |title=FOTW colour guide |website=Flags of the World |year=2015 |accessdate=5 June 2016}} == Flag == The organization's flag is a design by Mark Sensen, which was selected over 10 challengers in a poll of FOTW mailing list members and was adopted 8 March 1996. Since then, March 8 has been regarded as FOTW's [[Flag day]]. Sensen described its symbolism: {{quote|text=White on the hoist stands for peace, blue on the fly for progress. The six colours of the stars are the main colours used in flags. The stars help to make one bigger symbol. The way the stars are all connected to each other represents the Internet.{{cite web |url=http://flagspot.net/flags/fotwprfl.html |title=FOTW Official Flag |website=Flags of the World |accessdate=19 October 2007}}}} The flag is thus used as a rare representation of the [[Internet]] on a flag. == See also == * [[List of flags]] * [[List of flags by country]] (small view) * [[Gallery of sovereign-state flags|Gallery of country flags]] (larger-sized view) == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://flagspot.net/ Flags of the World] {{DEFAULTSORT:Flags Of The World}} [[Category:Online databases]] [[Category:International Federation of Vexillological Associations]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 1993]] [[Category:Internet resources on heraldry]]

revision.comment: A policy based consensus has been reached to remove this section from professional wrestling articles [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#Should the "In wrestling" section be removed from professional wrestling articles|Here]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox professional wrestler |name = Fritz Von Erich |image = Fritz Von Erich.jpg |image_size = 175px |birth_name = Jack Barton Adkisson |family= [[Von Erich family|Von Erich]] |names = Fritz Von Erich
Tetsu no Tsume (Iron Claw)
Jack Adkisson{{cite web|url=http://www.worldclasswrestling.info/2013/07/results-1953.html|title=World Class Memories: Results 1953|publisher=John Dananay/Michael Moody/ISE Web Productions|accessdate=2013-12-09|date=July 30, 2013}} |height = {{height|ft=6|in=4}} |weight = {{convert|260|lb|kg|abbr=on}} |birth_date = {{birth date|1929|8|16|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Jewett, Texas]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1997|9|10|1929|8|16|mf=y}}{{cite web|title=Von Erichs’ Patriarch Dead At 68|url=https://classicwrestlingarticles.wordpress.com/2013/08/19/von-erichs-patriarch-dead-at-68/|website=Classic Wrestling Articles|accessdate=16 August 2015}} |death_place = [[Dallas, Texas]] |death_cause=Brain and lung cancer |billed = [[Denton, Texas]] |trainer = [[Stu Hart]] |debut = 1953 |retired = 1982 }} '''Jack Barton Adkisson Sr.''' (August 16, 1929 – September 10, 1997) was an American [[Professional wrestling|professional wrestler]] known more under the [[ring name]] '''Fritz Von Erich''', better known today as a wrestling promoter and the patriarch of the [[Von Erich family]]. He was also the owner of the [[World Class Championship Wrestling]] territory.Foley, Mick. Have A Nice Day: A Tale of Blood and Sweatsocks (p.129) ==Football career== Adkisson attended [[Southern Methodist University]], where he threw discus and played football. He has been reported to have played with the now defunct [[Dallas Texans (NFL)|Dallas Texans]] of the [[NFL]] (not the [[American Football League|AFL]] team which became the [[Kansas City Chiefs]]),{{cite web|url=http://blog.chron.com/txpotomac/2010/01/today-in-texas-history-texas-gets-its-first-nfl-team/ |title=Today in Texas History: Texas gets its first NFL team|author=Dunham, Richard|accessdate=2014-07-09|date=January 24, 2010}} but this is not true.{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/players|quote=search historical players, Jack Adkisson|title=NFL PLAYERS}} He was signed as a guard but was cut.{{cite book|author=Hornbaker, Tim|title=National Wrestling Alliance: The Untold Story of the Monopoly That Strangled Pro Wrestling|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=npQBhSTtvCsC&pg=PT267&lpg=PT267&dq=jack+adkisson+jewett&source=bl&ots=_icTu9lI3e&sig=Jwgyx5NUtGRCzifLDu6Ca-R4uHQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xlCUVIOtLMWbyATs1YLYCQ&ved=0CF0Q6AEwDQ#v=onepage&q=jack%20adkisson%20jewett&f=false|year=2007|publisher=ECW Press|page=242|isbn=978-1-55022-741-3}} He then tried the [[Canadian Football League]] (CFL). ==Professional wrestling career== ===Early career and training=== While in [[Edmonton]], he met legendary wrestler and trainer [[Stu Hart]], and Hart decided to train and book him in his Klondike Wrestling promotion, naming him Fritz Von Erich and teaming him with "brother" [[Waldo Von Erich]] as a pair "evil German" brothers. Adkisson's oldest son Jack Barton Adkisson Jr. was born September 21, 1952. He died in 1959, however, after an accidental [[Electric shock|electrocution]] and [[drowning]], and Jack Sr. stopped traveling to the east coast, allowing former partner Waldo to use the Von Erich name in the [[World Wrestling Entertainment|World Wide Wrestling Federation]]. ===1960s=== Despite Jack Jr.'s death, Adkisson continued to travel and wrestle. Adkisson won both versions of the [[AWA World Heavyweight Championship|AWA World title]] in 1963. His major circuit was [[Sam Muchnick]]'s [[National Wrestling Alliance|NWA]] territorial [[St. Louis Wrestling Club|stronghold]] in [[St. Louis, Missouri]]. He wrestled there until 1967, when he voluntarily left the territory after losing a match for the [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship]] against then-champion [[Gene Kiniski]].Dave Meltzer, [[Wrestling Observer Newsletter]], January 9, 2008 In the late 1960s, with Muchnick's backing, Adkisson became the promoter for the [[Dallas]] territory, effectively overseeing the [[Houston]] and [[San Antonio]] territories, as well. ===Japan=== Adkisson was a part of rebuilding [[Professional wrestling in Japan|Japanese wrestling]] after the stabbing death of [[Rikidōzan]]. He became a star due to his feuds with [[Antonio Inoki]] and [[Shohei Baba|Giant Baba]], and his "Iron Claw" hold, which became one of the most popular wrestling moves in Japan. ===Retirement=== In 1982, he held his first retirement match against [[King Kong Bundy]] in the newly renamed [[World Class Championship Wrestling]] promotion, based in Dallas. The promotion was known for its high production values, use of entrance music and the use of [[television syndication]]. The promotion was one of the most successful territories in the United States, with major draws like his sons, [[The Fabulous Freebirds]], [[Chris Adams (wrestler)|Chris Adams]], [[Abdullah the Butcher]], [[Bruiser Brody]], [[Gino Hernandez]] and [[Rick Rude]]. By the end of the 1980s, the promotion's talent pool was thin and it was eventually merged with [[Jerry Jarrett]]'s [[Continental Wrestling Association]] to create the [[United States Wrestling Association]] in 1989. ==Personal life and death== {{See also|Von Erich family}} Adkisson married Doris J. Smith on June 23, 1950.[http://www.familytreelegends.com/records/31992?c=search&first=jack&last=adkisson Texas Divorces] Together, they had six sons: Jack Barton Jr. (September 21, 1952 - March 7, 1959), [[Kevin Von Erich|Kevin]] (born May 15, 1957), [[David Von Erich|David]] (July 22, 1958 - February 10, 1984), [[Kerry Von Erich|Kerry]] (February 3, 1960 – February 18, 1993), [[Mike Von Erich|Mike]] (March 2, 1964 – April 12, 1987) and [[Chris Von Erich|Chris]] (September 30, 1969 – September 12, 1991). Of Adkisson's six sons, only Kevin is still living. The couple later separated and Doris divorced her husband on July 21, 1992 after 42 years of marriage. Adkisson died of brain and lung cancer on September 10, 1997.{{cite web|url=http://www.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingArchive/sep11_fritz.html|title=Fritz Von Erich dead at 68|publisher=Slam! Sports|accessdate=2007-05-30|date=1997-09-11}} His [[funeral]] service was held at the First Baptist Church in [[Dallas, Texas]]. His body was cremated with his ashes interred in the same plot as his fourth son, Kerry. ==Championships and accomplishments== *'''[[All Japan Pro Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA International Tag Team Championship]] ([[NWA International Tag Team Championship#Title history|1 time]]) - with [[Killer Karl Krupp|Karl Krupp]] *'''[[Big Time Wrestling (Detroit)|Big Time Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA Detroit United States Heavyweight Championship|NWA United States Heavyweight Championship ''(Detroit Version)'']] ([[NWA Detroit United States Heavyweight Championship#Title history|3 times]]) *'''[[Maple Leaf Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA Canadian Open Tag Team Championship]] ([[NWA Canadian Open Tag Team Championship#Title history|3 times]]) - with Karl Von Schober (2) and [[Gene Kiniski]] (1) *'''[[Jim Crockett Promotions|Mid-Atlantic Championship Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA Southern Tag Team Championship (Mid-Atlantic version)]] ([[NWA Southern Tag Team Championship (Mid-Atlantic version)#Title history|1 time]]) - with [[Waldo Von Erich]] *'''[[American Wrestling Association|NWA Minneapolis Wrestling and Boxing Club]] / [[American Wrestling Association]]''' **[[AWA World Heavyweight Championship]] ([[List of AWA World Heavyweight Champions|1 time]]) **[[NWA Minneapolis World Tag Team Championship|NWA World Tag Team Championship ''(Minneapolis version)'']] ([[NWA Minneapolis World Tag Team Championship#Title history|1 time]]) - with Hans Hermann **[[World Heavyweight Championship (Omaha)]] ([[World Heavyweight Championship (Omaha)#title history|2 times]]) *'''[[NWA Western States Sports]]''' **NWA International Tag Team Championship ''(Amarillo version)'' (1 time) - with Killer Karl Krupp **[[NWA North American Heavyweight Championship (Amarillo version)|NWA North American Heavyweight Championship ''(Amarillo version)'']] ([[NWA North American Heavyweight Championship (Amarillo version)#Title history|4 times]]) *'''''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]''''' **PWI ranked him #'''207''' of the top 500 singles wrestlers of the "[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated|PWI Years]]" in 2003{{cite web|url=http://www.willywrestlefest.fr/Ressources/PWI/PWI500_PWI_Years_2003.htm|title=PWI 500 of the PWI Years|accessdate=2012-08-28|publisher=Willy Wrestlefest}} *'''[[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame]]''' :*[[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame#2012|Class of 2012]] *'''[[World Class Championship Wrestling|Southwest Sports, Inc]] / [[World Class Championship Wrestling|NWA Big Time Wrestling]] / [[World Class Championship Wrestling]]''' **[[WCWA World Heavyweight Championship|NWA American Heavyweight Championship]] ([[WCWA World Heavyweight Championship#Title history|13 times]]) **[[WCWA World Tag Team Championship|NWA American Tag Team Championship]] ([[WCWA World Tag Team Championship#Title history|7 times]]) - with [[Waldo Von Erich]] (2), [[Billy Red Lyons]] (1), [[Aurelian Smith|Grizzly Smith]] (1), [[Fred Curry (wrestler)|Fred Curry]] (1), Dan Miller (1), and Dean Ho (1) **[[NWA Texas Hardcore Championship|NWA Brass Knuckles Championship ''(Texas version)'']] ([[NWA Texas Hardcore Championship#Title history|5 times]]) **[[NWA Texas Heavyweight Championship]] ([[NWA Texas Heavyweight Championship#Title history|4 times]]) **[[WCWA World Heavyweight Championship|NWA United States Heavyweight Championship ''(Texas version)'']] ([[WCWA World Heavyweight Championship#Title history|3 times]]){{efn|This championship was later renamed the NWA American Heavyweight Championship in May 1968. It would later be renamed the WCWA World Heavyweight Championship after World Class' withdrawal from the NWA in February 1986.}} **[[WCWA World Six-Man Tag Team Championship|NWA World Six-Man Tag Team Championship ''(Texas version)'']] ([[WCWA World Six-Man Tag Team Championship#Title history|1 time]]) - with [[Kevin Von Erich|Kevin]] & [[Mike Von Erich]] **[[NWA Texas World Tag Team [[File:Gerrit David Gratama (1964).jpg|thumb|Gerrit David Gratama (1964)]] '''Gerrit David Gratama''' (22 March 1874 – 20 August 1965), was a Dutch artist, writer, and director of the [[Frans Hals Museum]].
==Biography== He was born in Groningen and was the brother of the architect [[Jan Gratama]]. He studied at [[Royal Academy of Art, The Hague|the Hague Academy of art]] during the years 1892-1895, and afterwards during the years 1895-1897 he continued his studies at the [[Royal Academy of Fine Arts (Antwerp)|Royal academy of art in Antwerp]].<ref name=Gratama>Obituary of Hendrik van Borssum Buisman (1 January 1873 - 15 October 1951) in Jaarboek Haerlem 1951, by G.D. Gratama, pp. 31-32, De Erven F. Bohn N.V., Haerlem, 1951</ref><ref name=RKD>[https://rkd.nl/en/explore/artists/33395 Gerrit David Gratama] in the [[RKD]]</ref> He was a pupil in Antwerp of [[Albrecht de Vriendt]] and [[Henri Heymans]] and a friend of [[Hendrik van Borssum Buisman]], [[Simon Maris]], [[Toon Dupuis]], [[Isidoor Opsomer]], [[Walter Vaes]] and H.J. Wouter.<ref name=Gratama/> In 1912 he was appointed director of the Frans Hals Museum, which meant that he oversaw the complete renovation of the former [[Oude Mannenhuis]] and the move of the collection from the upper floors of the [[City Hall (Haarlem)|City Hall]].<ref name=Hees>Obituary of Gerrit David Gratama (22 March 1874 - 21 August 1965) in Jaarboek Haerlem 1965, by Carla van Hees (C.A. de Goederen-van Hees), pp. 24-28, De Erven F. Bohn N.V., Haerlem, 1965</ref> Among his tasks were organizing exhibitions and keeping the museum catalog up-to-date, and for his 25th anniversary as director, he organized a Frans Hals monograph exhibition to celebrate the 75th birthday of the Haarlem municipal museum and wrote the Frans Hals Exhibition catalog in 1937 together with J.L.A.A.M. van Rijckevoorsel.<ref>[[:Commons:Frans Hals Exhibition catalog, 1937|Frans Hals Exhibition catalog, 1937]] on Commons</ref>
He was hired not only as a curator and director, but was also artist-in-residence at the museum and kept a studio there. He was known for his portraits and still-life paintings.<ref name=Hees/> He retired officially in 1940, but was asked to stay on during the war and oversaw the storage of the collection highlights in the dunes. He did retire after 33 years in 1946, but he continued as a painter into old age.<ref name=Hees/> He was succeeded as director of the museum by [[Henricus Petrus Baard]]. He died in Haarlem.
==Works== [[File:Frans Hals tentoonstelling Haarlem 1937.JPG|thumb|Cover of the 1937 Frans Hals exhibition catalog featuring [[Two laughing boys with mug of beer]]]] *''Caricaturen van den tulpenhandel'', * ''Frans Hals : regenten en regentessen van het Oudemannenhuis'' * ''Frans Hals Museum der Gemeente Haarlem'', 1913 * ''Frans Hals'', Frans Halsmuseum, 1920 * ''Frans Hals tentoonstelling ter gelegenheid van het 75-jarig bestaan van het gemeentelijk museum te Haarlem op 30 juni 1937'' * ''Nabetrachting betreffende de Frans Hals-tentoonstelling : identificatie, critiek'' * ''Frans Hals'', 1946 *''Het portret van Jan Neyen door Rubens'' *''Rondgang door het Frans Hals Museum''
{{Commons|Frans Hals Exhibition catalog, 1937}}

{{Notability|Products|date=April 2011}} <!-- {{Refimprove}} --> {{Infobox software | name = Google Public Data Explorer | logo = Google 2015 logo.svg | screenshot = Insurance Trust Revenue vs Insurance Trust Expenditure.jpg | caption = Example of an animated bubble plot.<ref name=KE>{{cite web|last1=Edwards|first1=Kerstin|title=Visualizing Data from Government Census and Surveys: Plans for the Future|url=http://www2.census.gov/govs/pubs/research_reports/data_visualization.pdf|publisher=U.S. Census Bureau|accessdate=20 January 2015}}</ref> | developer = [[Google Inc.]] | released = {{Start date and age|df=yes|2010|03|08}} | platform = [[Web application|Web platform]] | language count = 40 | language footnote = {{Citation needed|date=February 2018}} | genre = [[Collaborative software]], [[Data visualization]] | website = {{URL|https://www.google.com/publicdata/}}<!-- "www." part is mandatory --> }} '''Google Public Data Explorer''' provides public [[data]] and [[forecasts]] from a range of international organizations and academic institutions including the [[World Bank]], [[OECD]], [[Eurostat]] and the [[University of Denver]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Pardee Center for International Futures Data Explorer|url=http://pardee.du.edu/google-data-explorer|publisher=University of Denver|accessdate=18 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Data Providers|url=https://www.google.com/publicdata/directory|publisher=Google|accessdate=18 January 2015}}</ref> These can be displayed as line graphs, bar graphs, cross sectional plots or on maps.<ref>{{cite web|title=Visualize the data in a dataset|url=https://support.google.com/publicdata/answer/1100976?hl=en&ref_topic=1100638|publisher=Google|accessdate=18 January 2015}}</ref> The product was launched on March 8, 2010 as an experimental visualization tool in [[Google Labs]].<ref name=GB20100308>{{cite web|title=Statistics for a changing world: Google Public Data Explorer in Labs|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2010/03/statistics-for-changing-world-google.html|publisher=Google|accessdate=20 January 2015}}</ref>
In 2011 the Public Data Explorer was made available for anyone to upload, share and visualize data sets. To facilitate this, Google created a new data format, the Dataset Publishing Language (DSPL). Once the data is imported, a dataset can be visualized, embedded in external websites, and shared with others like a [[Google Docs|Google Doc]].<ref name="SEL2011">{{cite web|last1=Sherman|first1=Chris|title=Visualize Your Own Information With Google Public Data Explorer|url=http://searchengineland.com/visualize-your-own-information-with-google-public-data-explorer-65081|publisher=Search Engine Land|accessdate=19 January 2015}}</ref>
In 2016, this toolset was enhanced with the [https://www.google.com/analytics/360-suite/analytics/ Google Analytics Suite], particularly [https://www.google.com/analytics/360-suite/data-studio/ Data Studio 360], whose release [https://analytics.googleblog.com/2016/05/announcing-data-studio-our-free-new.html expanded to a free public beta in May 2016], which enabled import of public or individual datasets and overlaid user-friendly (non-coding) data visualization tools.
== SDMX conversion == The [[SDMX]] converter is an open source application, which offers the ability to convert DSPL (Google's Dataset Publishing Language) messages to SDMX-ML and backwards. The output file of a DSPL dataset is a zip file containing data ([[Comma-separated values|CSV]] files) and metadata ([[XML]] file). Datasets in this format can be processed by Google and visualized in the Google Public Data Explorer.<ref>{{cite web|title=SDMX Converter|url=https://webgate.ec.europa.eu/fpfis/mwikis/sdmx/index.php/SDMX_Converter|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=25 January 2015}}</ref>

{{convert|500|LT|t|0|lk=in|abbr=on}} |Ship tons burthen= |Ship length=*{{convert|179|ft|6|in|m|abbr=on}} [[spar (sailing)|spar]]red length *{{convert|135|ft|6|in|m|abbr=on}} on [[Deck (ship)|deck]] *{{convert|114|ft|6|in|m|abbr=on}} [[Length at the waterline|w/l]] |Ship beam={{convert|32|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship height= of [[Rigging|Rig]] {{convert|130|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship draft={{convert|13|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship decks= |Ship deck clearance= |Ship propulsion= |Ship sail plan=[[Full rigged ship]], sail area {{convert|13000|ft2|m2|abbr=on}} |Ship speed= |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship boats= |Ship complement= |Ship crew= |Ship armament=28 x 9 pound cannons (non-operational) |Ship notes= }} |} '''"HMS" ''Surprise''''' is a modern [[tall ship]] built at [[Lunenburg, Nova Scotia|Lunenburg]], [[Nova Scotia]]. The vessel was built in 1970 as '''HMS ''Rose''''' to a [[Phil Bolger]] design based on the original 18th-century British [[Admiralty]] drawings of {{HMS|Rose|1757|6}}, a 20-gun [[sixth-rate]] [[post ship]] from 1757.
==As HMS ''Rose''== The ship was meant to be a close replica of the original ''Rose'', but still fill a commercial function. John Fitzhugh Millar<ref>{{cite web|last1=Millar|first1=John F.|title=Building the Replicas of Revolutionary War Ships Rose and Providence|url=http://smallstatebighistory.com/building-replicas-revolutionary-war-ships-rose-providence/|website=smallstatebighistory.com|accessdate=22 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Millar|first1=J. F.|title=John Fitzhugh Millar|url=http://www.newporthousebb.com/photo_album/page22/|website=newporthousebb.com|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref> who commissioned the ship build gave Bolger copies of the original British Admiralty drawings, Bolger modified the hull shape below the water line, sharpening up her entry so she sailed to windward better. Unlike some square-riggers, she could sail two points (22-1/2 degrees) on the wind provided that seas remained under four feet or so. Bolger also changed the arrangement of her decks, at the banks insistence, so that she could be used as a tavern and restaurant, though she was never used as such.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bolger|first1=Philip C.|title=30-Odd Boats|date=1982|publisher=International Marine Publishing Company|isbn=0877421528}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=HMS Rose Sails Soon|journal=Boating|issue=October 1969|page=85|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=nHv-v3JYFgYC&lpg=RA4-PA85&ots=VM07Gf6m_y&dq=phil%20bolger%20book%20AND%20HMS%20Rose&pg=RA4-PA85#v=onepage&q=phil%20bolger%20book%20AND%20HMS%20Rose&f=false|accessdate=21 December 2017}}</ref>
''Rose'' was built at the [[Smith and Rhuland]] shipyard in Lunenburg, a yard which had established a reputation for large and successful replicas such as HMS {{ship||Bounty|1960 ship|2}} in 1960 and {{ship||Bluenose II}} in 1963.
The ship was inspected and certified by the [[United States Coast Guard]]. She spent the first ten years of her life in Newport, Rhode Island sailing in Newport Harbor and as a dockside attraction. In 1984, already in serious disrepair, she was purchased by Kaye Williams<ref>{{cite book|last1=Biebel|first1=Frederick|title=Path of a Patriot|date=2008|isbn=0615236650|page=186|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=8sT2AgAAQBAJ&lpg=PA186&ots=OYVRzkFl0h&dq=hms%20rose%20replica&pg=PA186#v=onepage&q=hms%20rose%20replica&f=false}}</ref> and brought to Bridgeport, Connecticut, and operated as a [[sail training]] vessel in the 1980s and 1990s, run by the HMS Rose Foundation based in [[Bridgeport, Connecticut|Bridgeport]], [[Connecticut]], [[United States]]. In her lifetime as ''Rose'', her figurehead had to be replaced twice, each time slightly upgraded. One was damaged in a storm off Bermuda on her way to [[Norfolk, Virginia]] in June 1998. The figurehead was named in fun as "Chester" by the crew.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nyden|first1=W. A.|title=Vacation June 1998|url=http://www.nyden.us/roserpt.html|website=nyden.us|accessdate=25 December 2017}}</ref>
In the summer of 1972, ''Rose'' was hired for the film "''[[The Man Without a Country (1973 film)|The Man Without a Country]]''", a made-for-television production. Norman Rosemont Productions couldn't find the money to take the ship out sailing, so all the filming was shot with sails set, as the ship was securely moored to the pier, next to the causeway to [[Goat Island (Rhode Island)|Goat Island]]. During filming Cliff Robertson had to hide that he had a broken leg at the time.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Millar|first1=John Fitzhugh|title=Building the Replicas of Revolutionary War Ships Rose and Providence|url=http://smallstatebighistory.com/building-replicas-revolutionary-war-ships-rose-providence/|website=smallstatebighistory|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref>
Late in the 1990s, the publisher W. W. Norton & Company rented ''Rose'' in New York for a pier-side party to celebrate the publication of [[Patrick O'Brian]]'s latest novel. O'Brian himself was present, and he casually mentioned to ''Rose''{{'}}s captain Richard Bailey that if ''Rose'' were painted in an 1805 colour scheme she would be a "dead ringer" for the frigate ''Surprise'' that appeared in his books. Bailey quickly ordered his crew to get out the paint and make the changes. O'Brian was so impressed that he changed his mind about his prohibition of having any of his books converted into film, and Norton immediately started looking for a Hollywood production company.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Millar|first1=John Fitzhugh|title=Building the Replicas of Revolutionary War Ships Rose and Providence|url=http://smallstatebighistory.com/building-replicas-revolutionary-war-ships-rose-providence/|website=smallstatebighistory|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref> [[File:HMS Rose - 1971 under sail off Massachusetts.png|thumb|200px|right|Replica HMS ''Rose'' off Massachusetts in 1971, the hull painted as her namesake]]
==Transformation into HMS ''Surprise''==
The ship was sold to the [[20th Century Fox]] film studio in March 2001,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cummings|first1=Bill|title=Goodbye, Rose: Filmmaker Pays $1.5m for Bridgeport Frigate|url=http://www.peterweircave.com/master/rose1.html|accessdate=17 December 2017}}</ref> and underwent extensive modifications to be used in the making of the film ''[[Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World]]'', in which she portrayed the [[Royal Navy]] frigate HMS {{HMS|Surprise|1796|2}} with a story based on several of the books by Patrick O'Brian. The modifications included a reshaped stern, all deck structures removed, the single ship's wheel replaced by a double wheel, period fighting tops fitted, new sails, and the figurehead replaced.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Quinlan|first1=Eric|title=Cross Currents|journal=Yachting|date=Nov 2003|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ZPTPomKTxHsC&lpg=PA24&ots=JdRea5AnXt&dq=hms%20surprise%20extensive%20modifications&pg=PA24#v=onepage&q=hms%20surprise%20extensive%20modifications&f=false|accessdate=17 December 2017}}</ref>
==Renaming as HMS ''Surprise''== After the film was complete, the ship was leased and then purchased by the [[Maritime Museum of San Diego]] which has restored her to sailing condition as of September 2007.<ref>[http://legacy.sname.org/sections/san_diego/Presentations/2007-10_Reviving_Surprise.pdf "Reviving Surprise"(pdf) David L. Kolthoff, P.E.]</ref> The ship has officially been re-registered as "HMS ''Surprise''" in honor of her role in the film. She sails several times a year, often with the museum's other tall ships, the schooner {{ship||Californian|schooner|2}} and the 1863 barque {{ship||Star of India|ship|2}}.<ref>[http://www.sdmaritime.com/contentpage.asp?ContentID=152 SDMM article on ''Surprise''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050405203518/http://www.sdmaritime.com/ContentPage.asp?ContentID=152 |date=2005-04-05 }}</ref> In 2010, she portrayed HMS ''Providence'' in the [[Disney]] [[adventure film]] ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides]]''.<ref>http://img835.imageshack.us/slideshow/webplayer.php?id=lb1f.jpg</ref>
==Related facts== Although she is known by the prefix '''HMS''', meaning Her (or His) [[Her Majesty's Ship|Majesty's Ship]], she is not, and had never been, [[Ship commissioning|commissioned]] in the Royal Navy and therefore had no right to use this prefix.
In 1991, The [[Connecticut General Assembly]] passed "An Act Concerning the HMS Rose" in which the ship was commissioned as a vessel of the [[Connecticut Naval Militia]]. The act stated that the H.M.S. Rose Foundation was responsible for maintaining the ship, but when the ship was sold to 20th Century Fox, the statute was not repealed and is still in effect.<ref>[http://www.cga.ct.gov/current/pub/chap_504.htm#sec_27-5 CGS 27-5 - Public Act 91-31]</ref>
[[File:HMS Rose - 2000 coming into Baltimore 51741315 265eec262c.jpg|thumb|300px|right|''HMS Rose'' in 2000 painted to resemble the original ''Surprise'' coming into Baltimore]]

'''''Hitzeroth v Brooks''''' is an important case in the [[South African]] law of lease, in which Hitzeroth instituted action for the ejectment of Brooks from certain property. Her cause of action was founded upon an undisputed [[allegation]] that she was the owner of the property and Brooks was in [[Crime|unlawful]] occupation thereof.
Brooks alleged that she was the cessionary of a [[lease]] which had been entered into between Hitzeroth's late husband as lessor and one Mrs Rodkey as lessee for a period of nine years and eleven months. This lease gave the lessee the right to renew the lease for a further period subject to the same [[terms and conditions]]. Furthermore, the lessee had the right either to [[sublet]] or to [[cede]] her rights to any other period for the unexpired portion of the lease or renewal thereof.
Mrs Rodkey had ceded her rights to Brooks.
When Brooks gave Hitzeroth written notice of her intention to renew the lease, Hitzeroth challenged the validity of the renewal and subsequently brought this action.
O'Hagan J held that the words "[[Third-party beneficiary|third parties]]" in section 2 of the General Law Amendment Act of 1956 should be so construed as to exclude from the operation of the proviso persons falling within the class comprising gratuitous successors to the lessor: that is, persons who, under the previous statute and the common law, were bound by a long lease whether or not they had notice, actual or constructive, of the existence of the lease.
Munnik J held that the words "third parties" in the section refer to those who are not parties to the lease or cession, but persons other than the original contracting parties can become parties to it, in which case they are not "third parties" within the meaning of the section.
== See also == * [[South African law of lease]]
== References == * ''Hitzeroth v Brooks'' 1965 (3) SA 444 (A).
