[[United States]] | origins = | key_people = [[Göran Marby]] (CEO and [[President (corporate title)|President]]), [[Cherine Chalaby]] ([[Chairman|Chair of the Board]]) | area_served = | product = | focus = Manage [[Internet Protocol]] numbers and [[Domain Name System]] root | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | owner = | motto = One World. One Internet. | homepage = [https://www.icann.org/ ICANN.org] | dissolved = | footnotes = }} {{Internet}} [[File:Icannheadquartersplayavista.jpg|thumb|right|ICANN headquarters in the [[Playa Vista, Los Angeles|Playa Vista]] neighborhood of Los Angeles]] The '''Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers''' ('''ICANN''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|aɪ|k|æ|n}} {{respell|EYE|kan}}) is a nonprofit organization responsible for coordinating the maintenance and procedures of several [[database]]s related to the [[namespace]]s and numerical spaces of the Internet, ensuring the network's stable and secure operation. ICANN performs the actual technical maintenance work of the Central Internet Address pools and [[DNS root zone]] registries pursuant to the [[Internet Assigned Numbers Authority]] (IANA) function contract. The contract regarding the IANA [[stewardship]] functions between ICANN and the [[National Telecommunications and Information Administration]] (NTIA) of the [[United States Department of Commerce]] ended on October 1, 2016, formally transitioning the functions to the global [[Multistakeholder governance model|multistakeholder community]].{{cite web|url=https://www.icann.org/news/blog/cheers-to-the-multistakeholder-community|title=Cheers to the Multistakeholder Community|publisher=ICANN}}{{cite web|url=https://www.icann.org/news/blog/final-implementation-update|title=Final Implementation Update|publisher=ICANN}}{{cite web|url=https://www.icann.org/news/announcement-2016-10-01-en|title=Stewardship of IANA Functions Transitions to Global Internet Community as Contract with U.S. Government Ends|publisher=ICANN}}{{cite web|title=Statement of Assistant Secretary Strickling on IANA Functions Contract|url=https://www.ntia.doc.gov/press-release/2016/statement-assistant-secretary-strickling-iana-functions-contract|publisher=[[National Telecommunications and Information Administration]]}} Much of its work has concerned the Internet's global [[Domain Name System]] (DNS), including policy development for internationalization of the DNS system, introduction of new generic [[top-level domains]] (TLDs), and the operation of [[root name server]]s. The numbering facilities ICANN manages include the [[Internet Protocol]] address spaces for [[IPv4]] and [[IPv6]], and assignment of address blocks to [[Regional Internet registry|regional Internet registries]]. ICANN also maintains registries of Internet Protocol identifiers. ICANN's primary principles of operation have been described as helping preserve the operational stability of the Internet; to promote competition; to achieve broad representation of the global Internet community; and to develop policies appropriate to its mission through [[Top-down and bottom-up design|bottom-up]], consensus-based processes. ICANN's creation was announced publicly on September 17, 1998 {{cite web|last=Postel|first=Jonathan|title=A Brief Explanation of the Joint IANA and NSI Documents Defining the New Internet Corporation|url=https://web.archive.org/web/19990219132906/http://www.netsol.com:80/policy/icann/}},and it formally came into being on September 30, 1998, incorporated in the U.S. state of California. Originally headquartered in [[Marina del Rey]] in the same building as the [[University of Southern California]]'s [[Information Sciences Institute]] (ISI)], its offices are now in the [[Playa Vista, Los Angeles|Playa Vista]] neighborhood of Los Angeles. ==History== Before the establishment of ICANN, the [[Internet Assigned Numbers Authority|IANA]] function of administering registries of Internet protocol identifiers (including the distributing top-level domains and IP addresses) was performed by [[Jon Postel]], a Computer Science researcher who had been involved in the creation of [[ARPANET]], first at [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]] and then at USC-ISI.{{cite ietf |rfc=2460 |title=I REMEMBER IANA |author=V. Cerf |date=October 17, 1998 |publisher=[[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]]}}{{cite web|last=Zittrain|first=Jonathan|title=No, Barack Obama Isn't Handing Control of the Internet Over to China|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/117093/us-withdraws-icann-why-its-no-big-deal|work=The New Republic|accessdate=March 31, 2014}} In 1997 Postel testified before Congress that this had come about as a "side task" to this research work.{{cite web|url=http://commdocs.house.gov/committees/science/hsy268140.000/hsy268140_0.HTM|title=Internet Domain Names, Part I|publisher=[[United States House of Representatives]]}} The Information Sciences Institute was funded by the [[United States Department of Defense|U.S. Department of Defense]], as was SRI International's Network Information Center, which also performed some assigned name functions.{{cite book|last=DeNardis|first=Laura|title=Protocol Politics: The Globalization of Internet Governance|date=2009|isbn=978-0-262-04257-4}} As the Internet grew and expanded globally, the [[United States Department of Commerce|U.S. Department of Commerce]] initiated a process to establish a new organization to perform the IANA functions. On January 30, 1998, the [[National Telecommunications and Information Administration]] (NTIA), an agency of the U.S. Department of Commerce, issued for comment, "A Proposal to Improve the Technical Management of Internet Names and Addresses." The proposed rule making, or "Green Paper",{{cite web|url=http://www.ntia.doc.gov/ntiahome/domainname/domainname130.htm|title=Internet Domain Names|first=|last=NTIA/PTO|website=www.ntia.doc.gov}} was published in the Federal Register on February 20, 1998, providing opportunity for public comment. NTIA received more than 650 comments as of March 23, 1998, when the comment period closed.{{cite web|title=Management of Internet Names and Addresses|url=http://www.ntia.doc.gov/files/ntia/publications/6_5_98dns.txt|publisher=Dept of Commerce/NTIA|accessdate=March 14, 2013}} The Green Paper proposed certain actions designed to privatize the management of Internet names and addresses in a manner that allows for the development of competition and facilitates global participation in Internet management. The Green Paper proposed for discussion a variety of issues relating to [[Domain Name System|DNS]] management including private sector creation of a new not-for-profit corporation (the "new corporation") managed by a globally and functionally representative board of directors.{{cite web|last1=Weil|first1=Nancy|title=New U.S. policy turns 'Net governance over to private sector|url=http://sunsite.uakom.sk/sunworldonline/swol-06-1998/swol-06-ntia.html|publisher=SunWorld|accessdate=April 21, 2015}} ICANN was formed in response to this policy.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} ICANN managed the [[Internet Assigned Numbers Authority]] (IANA) under contract to the [[United States Department of Commerce]] (DOC) and pursuant to an agreement with the [[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]].{{cite ietf |rfc=2860 |title=MoU Between IETF and ICANN concerning IANA |author=B. Carpenter, F. Baker, M. Roberts |date=June 2000 |publisher=[[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]]}} ICANN was incorporated in California on September 30, 1998, with entrepreneur and philanthropist [[Esther Dyson]] as founding chairwoman. It is a nonprofit public benefit corporation "organized under the California Nonprofit Public Benefit Corporation Law for charitable and public purposes."{{cite web|title=Articles of Incorporation of Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers|url=https://www.icann.org/resources/pages/articles-2012-02-25-en|publisher=Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers|accessdate=February 17, 2017|location=Los Angeles|date=November 21, 1998}} ICANN was established in California due to the presence of [[Jon Postel]], who was a founder of ICANN and was set to be its first [[Chief Technology Officer]] prior to his unexpected death. ICANN formerly operated from the same [[Marina del Rey, California|Marina del Rey]] building where Postel formerly worked, which is home to an office of the [[Information Sciences Institute]] at the [[University of Southern California]]. However, ICANN's headquarters is now located in the nearby [[Playa Vista, Los Angeles|Playa Vista]] neighborhood of [[Westside (Los Angeles County)|Los Angeles]]. Per its original [[by-law]]s,{{cite web|url=http://www.icann.org/en/about/governance/bylaws/bylaws-06nov98-en.htm#VI|title=ICANN|website=''icann.org''}} primary responsibility for policy formation in ICANN was to be delegated to three supporting organizations (Address Supporting Organization, Domain Name Supporting Organization, and Protocol Supporting Organization), each of which was to develop and recommend substantive policies and procedures for the management of the identifiers within their respective scope. They were also required to be financially independent from ICANN.{{cite web|title=Executive Summary of DNS/ICANN Issues|url=http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/pressbriefings/icann/briefingbook/executivesummaries.html#SOs|publisher=Berkman Center|accessdate=February 22, 2013}} As expected, the [[Regional Internet Registries]] and the [[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]] agreed to serve as the Address Supporting Organization and Protocol Supporting Organization respectively,{{cite web|title=Santiago Resolutions|url=https://archive.icann.org/en/meetings/santiago/santiago-resolutions.htm|work=ICANN Board Resolutions|publisher=ICANN|accessdate=May 22, 2012}}{{cite web|title=Executive Summary of DNS/ICANN Now, ICANN policy is being set by ambiguous so-called Communities. In a dramatic departure from IANA, ICANN has allowed secrecy and concealment of the true ownership of domain names. There are whole sets of nominee registrants whose purpose is to conceal the true ownership of domain names. Issues|url=http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/pressbriefings/icann/briefingbook/executivesummaries.html|work=Harvard Cyberlaw Briefing Book|publisher=Berkman Center|accessdate=May 21, 2012}} and ICANN issued a call for interested parties to propose the structure and composition of the Domain Name Supporting Organization.{{cite web|title=DNSO Application Timetable|url=http://www.dnso.org/history/www.dnso.org/docs/dnso-app-timetable.htm|publisher=DNSO|accessdate=May 21, 2012}} In March 1999, the ICANN Board, based in part on the DNSO proposals received, decided instead on an alternate construction for the DNSO which delineated specific constituencies bodies within ICANN itself,{{cite web|last=ICANN Board|title=DNSO Singapore Statement|url=http://archive.icann.org/en/meetings/singapore/singapore-statement.htm|publisher=ICANN|accessdate=May 21, 2012}}{{cite web|title=DNSO Formation Concepts|url=http://archive.icann.org/en/meetings/singapore/dnso-formation.htm|publisher=ICANN|accessdate=May 21, 2012}} thus adding primary responsibility for DNS policy development to ICANN's existing duties of oversight and coordination. On July 26, 2006, the United States government renewed the contract with ICANN for performance of the [[Internet Assigned Numbers Authority|IANA]] function for an additional one to five years. The context of ICANN's relationship with the U.S. government was clarified on September 29, 2006 when ICANN signed a new [[Memorandum of Understanding]] with the [[United States Department of Commerce]] (DOC). This document gave the DOC oversight over some of the ICANN operations. During July 2008, the DOC reiterated an earlier statement that it has "no plans to transition management of the authoritative [[root zone file]] to ICANN". The letter also stresses the separate roles of the [[Internet Assigned Numbers Authority|IANA]] and [[VeriSign]]. On September 30, 2009, ICANN signed an agreement with the DOC (known as the "Affirmation of Commitments") that confirmed ICANN's commitment to a [[multistakeholder governance model]],[http://www.zdnet.com/article/us-government-finally-lets-icann-go/ "US Government finally lets ICANN go"], Eileen Yu, [[ZDNet]], September 30, 2009. but did not remove it from DOC oversight and control. On March 10, 2016, ICANN and the DOC signed a historic, culminating agreement to finally remove ICANN and IANA from the control and oversight of the DOC.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/mar/14/icann-internet-control-domain-names-iana|title=Quietly, symbolically, US control of the internet was just ended|last=Farrell|first=Maria|date=March 14, 2016|newspaper=The Guardian|issn=0261-3077|access-date=March 17, 2016}} On October 1, 2016, ICANN was freed from U.S. government oversight.{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/tech/u-government-no-longer-controls-160017929.html|title=The U.S. government no longer controls the Internet|website=[[Yahoo! Tech]]}} ==Notable events== On March 18, 2002, publicly elected At-Large Representative for North America board member [[Karl Auerbach]] sued ICANN in Superior Court in California to gain access to ICANN's accounting records without restriction. Auerbach won. During September and October 2003, ICANN played a crucial role in the conflict over [[VeriSign]]'s "wild card" DNS service [[Site Finder]]. After an open letter from ICANN issuing an ultimatum to VeriSign, later endorsed by the [[Internet Architecture Board]], the company voluntarily ended the service on October 4, 2003. After this action, VeriSign filed a lawsuit against ICANN on February 27, 2004, claiming that ICANN had exceeded its authority. By this lawsuit, VeriSign sought to reduce ambiguity about ICANN's authority. The antitrust component of VeriSign's claim was dismissed during August 2004. VeriSign's challenge that ICANN overstepped its contractual rights is currently outstanding. A proposed settlement already approved by ICANN's board would resolve VeriSign's challenge to ICANN in exchange for the right to increase pricing on .com domains. At the meeting of ICANN in Rome, which took place from March 2 to 6, 2004, ICANN agreed to ask approval of the [[United States Department of Commerce|U.S. Department of Commerce]] for the [[Waiting List Service]] of VeriSign.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} On May 17, 2004, ICANN published a proposed budget for the year 2004–05. It included proposals to increase the openness and professionalism of its operations, and greatly increased its proposed spending from US$8.27 million to $15.83 million. The increase was to be funded by the introduction of new [[top-level domain]]s, charges to [[Domain name registry|domain registries]], and a fee for some domain name registrations, renewals and transfers (initially USD 0.20 for all domains within a country-code top-level domain, and USD 0.25 for all others).{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} The [[Council of European National Top Level Domain Registries]] (CENTR), which represents the [[Internet Assigned Numbers Authority|Internet registries]] of 39 countries, rejected the increase, accusing ICANN of a lack of financial prudence and criticizing what it describes as ICANN's "unrealistic political and operational targets". Despite the criticism, the registry agreement for the top-level domains jobs and travel includes a US$2 fee on every domain the licensed companies sell or renew. After a second round of negotiations during 2004, the TLDs [[.eu|eu]], [[.asia|{{not a typo|asia}}]], [[.travel|travel]], [[.jobs|jobs]], [[.mobi|mobi]], and [[.cat|cat]] were introduced during 2005. [[Image:Cerf's Up-marquee-20071031.jpg|thumb|ICANN meeting, Los Angeles USA, 2007. The sign refers to [[Vint Cerf]], then chairman of the board of directors, who is working on the so-called [[Interplanetary Internet]].]] On February 28, 2006, ICANN's board approved a settlement with VeriSign in the lawsuit resulting from SiteFinder that involved allowing VeriSign (the registry) to raise its registration fees by up to 7% a year. This was criticised by a few members of the [[U.S. House of Representatives]]' [[United States Senate Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship|Small Business Committee]]. During February 2007, ICANN began procedures to end accreditation of one of their registrars, [[RegisterFly]] amid charges and lawsuits involving fraud, and criticism of ICANN's management of the situation. ICANN has been the subject of criticism as a result of its handling of RegisterFly, and the harm caused to thousands of clients as a result of what has been termed ICANN's "laissez faire attitude toward customer allegations of fraud". On May 23, 2008, ICANN issued enforcement notices against ten accredited registrars and announced this through a press release entitled "'Worst Spam Offenders' Notified by ICANN, Compliance system working to correct Whois and other issues." This was largely in response to a report issued by [[KnujOn]], called "The 10 Worst Registrars" in terms of spam advertised junk product sites and compliance failure. The mention of the word "[[Spam (electronic)|spam]]" in the title of the ICANN memo is somewhat misleading since ICANN does not address issues of spam or email abuse. Website content and usage are not within ICANN's mandate. However, the KnujOn report details how various registrars have not complied with their contractual obligations under the Registrar Accreditation Agreement (RAA). The main point of the KnujOn research was to demonstrate the relationships between compliance failure, illicit product traffic, and spam. The report demonstrated that out of 900 ICANN accredited registrars, fewer than 20 held 90% of the web domains advertised in spam. These same registrars were also most frequently cited by KnujOn as failing to resolve complaints made through the Whois Data Problem Reporting System (WDPRS). On June 26, 2008, the ICANN Board started a [[.events|new process of TLD naming policy]] to take a "significant step forward on the introduction of new generic top-level domains." This program envisions the availability of many new or already proposed domains, as well a new application and implementation process. On October 1, 2008, ICANN issued breach notices against Joker and Beijing Innovative Linkage Technology Ltd. after further researching reports and complaints issued by KnujOn. These notices gave the registrars 15 days to fix their Whois investigation efforts. In 2010, ICANN approved a major review of its policies with respect to [[accountability]], transparency, and public participation by the [[Berkman Center for Internet and Society]] at [[Harvard University]]. This external review was an assistance of the work of ICANN's Accountability and Transparency Review team. On February 3, 2011, ICANN announced that it had distributed the last batch of its remaining IPv4 addresses to the world's five Regional Internet Registries, the organizations that manage IP addresses in different regions. These registries began assigning the final IPv4 addresses within their regions until they ran out completely. On June 20, 2011, the ICANN board voted to end most restrictions on the names of [[generic top-level domain]]s (gTLD). Companies and organizations became able to choose essentially arbitrary top-level Internet domain names. The use of non-Latin characters (such as Cyrillic, Arabic, Chinese, etc.) is also allowed in gTLDs. ICANN began accepting applications for new gTLDS on January 12, 2012. The initial price to apply for a new gTLD was set at $185,000 and the annual renewal fee is $25,000. Following the 2013 [[NSA spying scandal]], ICANN endorsed the [[Montevideo Statement]],[https://www.icann.org/news/announcement-2013-10-07-en Montevideo Statement on the Future of Internet Cooperation], ICANN, October 7, 2013. Retrieved November 27, 2016. although no direct connection between these can be proven.[http://www.internetgovernance.org/2014/02/19/do-the-nsa-revelations-have-anything-to-do-with-internet-governance/ Do the NSA revelations have anything to do with Internet governance?], Internet Governance Project, February 19, 2014. Retrieved November 27, 2016 On October 1, 2016, ICANN ended its contract with the United States Department of Commerce National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) and entered the private sector.{{Cite web|url=https://www.icann.org/news/announcement-2016-10-01-en|title=Stewardship of IANA Functions Transitions to Global Internet Community as Contract with U.S. Government Ends – ICANN|website=''icann.org''|access-date=October 1, 2016}} The EU attempts to enforce its [[GDPR]] (active since May 25, 2018) shall impact on ICANN operations, which the latter tried to fix through last-minute changes.{{clarification needed|date=June 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/icann-makes-last-minute-whois-changes-to-address-gdpr-requirements/|title=ICANN makes last minute WHOIS changes to address GDPR requirements - ZDNet|first=Steven J.|last=Vaughan-Nichols|publisher=}} The deadline coincided with French President Macron's hosting of megatech bosses such as Facebook CEO [[Mark Zuckerberg]], Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella, Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi, IBM CEO Ginni Rometty, Intel CEO Brian Krzanich, Samsung President Young Sohn, and SAP CEO [[Bill McDermott]]. ==Structure== From its founding to the present, ICANN has been formally organized as a nonprofit corporation "for charitable and public purposes" under the California Nonprofit Public Benefit Corporation Law. It is managed by a 16-member board of directors composed of eight members selected by a nominating committee on which all the constituencies of ICANN are represented; six representatives of its Supporting Organizations, sub-groups that deal with specific sections of the policies under ICANN's purview; an at-large seat filled by an at-large organization; and the President / CEO, appointed by the board.[https://www.icann.org/en/about/governance/bylaws#VI BYLAWS FOR INTERNET CORPORATION FOR ASSIGNED NAMES AND NUMBERS | A California Nonprofit Public-Benefit Corporation]. ICANN. Retrieved April 28, 2014. There are currently three supporting organizations: the Generic Names Supporting Organization (GNSO) deals with policy making on [[generic top-level domain]]s (gTLDs);{{cite web|url=https://icannwiki.org/Generic_Names_Supporting_Organization|title=Generic Names Supporting Organization|publisher= ICANNWiki}} the [[Country Code Names Supporting Organization]] (ccNSO) deals with policy making on [[country-code top-level domain]]s (ccTLDs); the [[Address Supporting Organization]] (ASO) deals with policy making on IP addresses.{{cite web|title=Bylaws For Internet Corporation For Assigned Names And Numbers|url=https://www.icann.org/resources| website=''icann.org''|location=Go to Governance, Bylaws, ARTICLE VIII-Article X| date=February 25, 2012}} ICANN also relies on some advisory committees and other advisory mechanisms to receive advice on the interests and needs of stakeholders that do not directly participate in the Supporting Organizations.{{cite web|title=Bylaws For Internet Corporation For Assigned Names And Numbers|url=https://www.icann.org/resources| website=''icann.org''|location=Go to Governance, Bylaws, ARTICLE XI and ARTICLE XI-A| date=February 25, 2012}} These include the Governmental Advisory Committee (GAC), which is composed of representatives of a large number of national governments from all over the world; the [[At-Large Advisory Committee]] (ALAC), which is composed of individual Internet users from around the world selected by each of the Regional At-Large Organizations (RALO){{cite web|url=https://community.icann.org/display/atlarge/Regional+At-Large+Organisations|title=Regional At-Large Organisations – ALAC – Confluence|website=community.icann.org}} and Nominating Committee; the Root Server System Advisory Committee, which provides advice on the operation of the DNS root server system; the Security and Stability Advisory Committee (SSAC), which is composed of Internet experts who study security issues pertaining to ICANN's mandate; and the Technical Liaison Group (TLG), which is composed of representatives of other international technical organizations that focus, at least in part, on the Internet.{{cite web|title=Bylaws For Internet Corporation For Assigned Names And Numbers|url=https://www.icann.org/resources| website=''icann.org''|location=Go to Governance, Bylaws, ARTICLE XI and ARTICLE XI-A, Section 2| date=February 25, 2012}} ===Governmental Advisory Committee=== [[File:ICANN Government Advisory Committee.png|{{largethumb}}|Governmental Advisory Committee representatives]] ====Representatives==== The Governmental Advisory Committee has representatives from 111 states (108 [[Member states of the United Nations|UN members]], the [[Holy See]], [[Cook Islands]], [[Niue]] and [[Chinese Taipei|Taiwan]]), Hong Kong, [[Bermuda]], [[Montserrat]], the [[European Commission]] and the [[African Union Commission]].{{cite web|url=https://gacweb.icann.org/display/gacweb/GAC+Representatives|title=GAC Representatives – GAC Website (Main)|website=gacweb.icann.org}} ====Observers==== In addition the following organizations are GAC Observers:{{cite web|url=https://gacweb.icann.org/display/gacweb/GAC+Observers|title=GAC Observers – GAC Website (Main)|website=gacweb.icann.org}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[African Telecommunications Union]] * [[Asia-Pacific Telecommunity]] * [[Caribbean Telecommunications Union]] (CTU) * [[Commonwealth Telecommunications Organisation]] (CTO) * [[Council of Europe]] * [[Economic Commission for Africa]] (ECA) * [[European Broadcasting Union]] * [[European Organization for Nuclear Research]] (CERN) * [[European Space Agency]] * [[International Labour Office]] * [[International Telecommunication Union]] (ITU) * [[International Criminal Police Organization]] (INTERPOL) * [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement]] * [[Latin American Association of Telecom Regulatory Agencies]] (REGULATEL) * [[League of Arab States]] * [[New Partnership for Africa's Development]] (NEPAD) * [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] * [[Organization for Islamic Cooperation|The Organization for Islamic Cooperation]] * [[Organization of American States]] * [[Organisation internationale de la Francophonie]] (OIF) * [[Pacific Islands Forum]] * [[Secretariat of the Pacific Community]] (SPC) * [[Inter-American Telecommunication Commission]] (CITEL) * [[International Criminal Court]] * [[United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organization]] (UNESCO) * [[Universal Postal Union]] * [[World Bank]] * [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) * [[World Intellectual Property Organization]] (WIPO) * [[World Meteorological Organization]] * [[World Trade Organization]] {{div col end}} ====Key holders==== * [[Moussa Guebre]] * [[Dan Kaminsky]] * [[Paul Kane (entrepreneur)|Paul Kane]] * [[Norm Ritchie]] * [[Ondrej Sury]] * [[Bevil Wooding]] * [[Jiankang Yao]] ===Democratic input=== In the [[Memorandum of understanding]] that set up the relationship between ICANN and the U.S. government, ICANN was given a mandate requiring that it operate "in a bottom up, consensus driven, democratic manner." However, the attempts that ICANN have made to establish an [[organizational structure]] that would allow wide input from the global Internet community did not produce results amenable to the current Board. As a result, the At-Large constituency and direct election of board members by the global Internet community were soon abandoned. ICANN [[List of ICANN meetings|holds periodic public meetings]] rotated between continents for the purpose of encouraging global participation in its processes. Resolutions of the ICANN Board, preliminary reports, and minutes of the meetings, are published on the ICANN website, sometimes in real time. However, there are criticisms from ICANN constituencies including the Noncommercial Users Constituency (NCUC){{cite web|url=http://gnso.icann.org/about/stakeholders-constituencies/ncsg/ncuc|title=Non-Commercial Users – Generic Names Supporting Organization|website=gnso.icann.org}} and the [[At-Large Advisory Committee]] (ALAC) that there is not enough [[Freedom of information legislation|public disclosure]] and that too many discussions and decisions take place out of sight of the public.{{citation needed|date=March 2010}} During the early 2000s, there had been speculation that the United Nations might assume control of ICANN, followed by a negative reaction from the U.S. government and worries about a division of the Internet. The [[World Summit on the Information Society]] in Tunisia during November 2005 agreed not to get involved in the day-to-day and technical operations of ICANN. However it also agreed to establish an international [[Internet Governance Forum]], with a consultative role on the future governance of the Internet. ICANN's Government Advisory Committee is currently established to provide advice to ICANN regarding public policy issues and has participation by many of the world's governments. Some have attempted to argue that ICANN was never given the authority to decide policy, e.g., choose new TLDs or exclude other interested parties who refuse to pay ICANN's US$185,000 fee, but was to be a technical caretaker. Critics{{who|date=February 2011}} suggest that ICANN should not be allowed to impose business rules on market participants, and that all TLDs should be added on a [[first-come, first-served]] basis and the market should be the arbiter of who succeeds and who does not.{{citation needed|date=December 2007}} ==Activities== ===Uniform Domain-Name Dispute Resolution Policy (UDRP)=== One task that ICANN was asked to do was to address the issue of domain name ownership resolution for [[generic top-level domain]]s (gTLDs). ICANN's attempt at such a policy was drafted in close cooperation with the [[World Intellectual Property Organization]] (WIPO), and the result has now become known as the [[Uniform Domain-Name Dispute-Resolution Policy|Uniform Dispute Resolution Policy]] (UDRP). This policy essentially attempts to provide a mechanism for rapid, cheap and reasonable resolution of domain name conflicts, avoiding the traditional court system for disputes by allowing cases to be brought to one of a set of bodies that arbitrate domain name disputes. According to ICANN policy, a domain registrant must agree to be bound by the UDRP—they cannot get a domain name without agreeing to this. Examination of the UDRP decision patterns has caused some to conclude that compulsory domain name arbitration is less likely to give a fair hearing to domain name owners asserting defenses under the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] and other laws, compared to the federal courts of appeal in particular. ===Proposed elimination of public DNS whois=== In 2013, the initial report of ICANN's Expert Working Group has recommended that the present form of [[Whois]], a utility that allows anyone to know who has registered a domain name on the Internet, should be "abandoned". It recommends it be replaced with a system that keeps most registration information secret (or "gated") from most Internet users, and only discloses information for "permissible purposes".{{cite web|title=Initial Report from the Expert Working Group on gTLD Directory Services: A Next Generation Registration Directory Service|url=https://www.icann.org/en/groups/other/gtld-directory-services/initial-report-24jun13-en.pdf|publisher=ICANN Expert Working Group|date=June 24, 2013|accessdate=September 23, 2013}}{{cite news|last1=Murphy|first1=Kevin|title=Whois "killer" is a recipe for a clusterfuck|url=http://domainincite.com/16855-whois-killer-is-a-recipe-for-a-clusterfuck|accessdate=June 21, 2014|publisher=Domain Incite|date=June 13, 2014}} ICANN's list of permissible purposes includes domain name research, domain name sale and purchase, regulatory enforcement, personal data protection, legal actions, and abuse mitigation.[http://www.cpaglobal.com/newlegalreview/5558/icann_earmarks_domains_record_ Intellectual Property Solutions & Legal Support Services] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921054828/http://www.cpaglobal.com/newlegalreview/5558/icann_earmarks_domains_record_ |date=September 21, 2013 }}. CPA Global. Retrieved April 28, 2014. Whois has been a key tool of investigative journalists interested in determining who was disseminating information on the Internet.[http://jour.sc.edu/news/csj/CSJNov04.html Sjmc: Common Sense Journalism]. Jour.sc.edu. Retrieved April 28, 2014. The use of whois by the free press is not included in the list of permissible purposes in the initial report. ==Criticism== Since its creation, ICANN has been the subject of criticism and controversy.{{cite journal|last1=Fuller|first1=Kathleen E.|date=February 14, 2001|title=ICANN: The Debate Over Governing the Internet|url=http://scholarship.law.duke.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1000&context=dltr|format=PDF|journal=Duke Law & Technology Review|publisher=[[Duke University]]|accessdate=September 20, 2014}}{{Cite thesis|last=Malcolm|first=Jeremy|title=Multi-Stakeholder Public Policy Governance and its Application to the Internet Governance Forum|type=PhD|chapter=2.1.3. Criticisms|url=https://www.malcolm.id.au/thesis/sec-icann-criticisms.html|year=2008|publisher=[[Murdoch University]]|accessdate=September 20, 2014|oclc=436943765}} In 2000, professor Michael Froomkin of the [[University of Miami School of Law]] argued that ICANN's relationship with the U.S. Department of Commerce is illegal, in violation of either the [[United States Constitution|Constitution]] or [[United States Code|federal statutes]].{{cite journal|last1=Froomkin|first1=Michael|date=October 2000|title=Wrong Turn in Cyberspace|url=http://personal.law.miami.edu/~froomkin/articles/icann.pdf|format=PDF|journal=[[Duke Law Journal]]|publisher=[[Duke University School of Law]]|volume=50|issue=17|issn=0012-7086|lccn=sf82007022|oclc=1567016|accessdate=September 20, 2014}} In 2009, the new ''Affirmation of Commitments'' agreement between ICANN and the U.S. Department of Commerce, that aimed to create international oversight, ran into criticism.{{cite web|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/172986/article.html|title=New ICANN Agreement Runs into Criticism|last1=Gross|first1=Grant|date=October 1, 2009|work=[[PC World]]|accessdate=September 20, 2014}} During December 2011, the [[Federal Trade Commission]] stated ICANN had long failed to provide safeguards that protect consumers from online [[Charlatan|swindlers]].{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/12/22/tech/web/icann/|title=Keepers of the Internet face their greatest challenges ever|last1=Milian|first1=Mark|date=December 21, 2011|publisher=[[CNN]]|accessdate=September 20, 2014}} Also during 2011, seventy-nine companies, including [[The Coca-Cola Company]], [[Hewlett-Packard]], [[Samsung]] and others, signed a petition against ICANN's new TLD program (sometimes referred to as a "commercial landgrab"{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2012/jun/13/icann-criticised-commercial-landgrab-internet|title=Icann criticised over 'commercial landgrab' of internet|last1=Arthur|first1=Charles|date=June 13, 2012|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=September 20, 2014}}), in a group organized by the [[Association of National Advertisers]].{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/alltechconsidered/2012/06/13/154960405/icanns-call-for-new-domain-names-brings-criticism-and-357-million|title=ICANN's Call For New Domain Names Brings Criticism, And $357 Million|last1=Chappell|first1=Bill|date=June 14, 2012|publisher=[[NPR]]|accessdate=September 20, 2014}} As of September 2014, this group, the [[Coalition for Responsible Internet Domain Oversight]], that opposes the rollout of ICANN's TLD expansion program, has been joined by 102 associations and 79 major companies.{{cite web|url=http://www.ana.net/content/show/id/crido|title=Coalition for Responsible Internet Domain Oversight (CRIDO)|publisher=[[Association of National Advertisers|ANA]]|accessdate=September 20, 2014}} Partly as a response to this criticism, ICANN initiated an effort to protect trademarks in domain name registrations, which eventually culminated in the establishment of the [[Trademark Clearinghouse]]. ===IBSA proposal (2011)=== One controversial proposal, resulting from a September 2011 summit between India, Brazil, and South Africa (IBSA), would seek to move Internet governance into a "UN Committee on Internet-Related Policy" (UN-CIRP).{{cite news|title=Muzzlers of the Free Internet|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/indiahome/indianews/article-2220692/How-India-helped-bunch-bureaucrats-custodians-Internet.html|publisher=Mail Today (New Delhi, India)|accessdate=March 15, 2013|location=London|first=Sandeep|last=Bamzai|date=October 20, 2012}}[http://www.culturalivre.org.br/artigos/IBSA_recommendations_Internet_Governance.pdf "Recommendations from the IBSA (India-Brazil-South Africa) Multistakeholder meeting on Global Internet Governance"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005063245/http://www.culturalivre.org.br/artigos/IBSA_recommendations_Internet_Governance.pdf |date=October 5, 2011 }}, September 1–2, 2011, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil The action was a reaction to a perception that the principles of the 2005 Tunis Agenda for the Information Society have not been met.[http://www.itu.int/wsis/docs2/tunis/off/6rev1.html "Tunis Agenda for the Information Society"], World Summit on the Information Society, November 18, 2005 The statement proposed the creation of a new political organization operating as a component of the United Nations to provide policy recommendations for the consideration of technical organizations such as ICANN and international bodies such as the ITU.{{cite web|title=India's Statement Proposing UN Committee for Internet-Related Policy|url=http://cis-india.org/internet-governance/blog/india-statement-un-cirp/|publisher=Centre for Internet and Society|accessdate=August 20, 2015}} Subsequent to public criticisms, the Indian government backed away from the proposal.{{cite web|last=Kaul|first=Mahima|title=India changes its internet governance position – backs away from UN proposal|url=http://uncut.indexoncensorship.org/2012/10/india-internet-governance/|publisher=UNCUT|accessdate=March 15, 2013}} ===Montevideo Statement on the Future of Internet Cooperation (2013)=== On October 7, 2013 the [[Montevideo Statement]] on the Future of Internet Cooperation was released by the managers of a number of organizations involved in coordinating the Internet's global technical infrastructure, loosely known as the "I*" (or "I-star") group. Among other things, the statement "expressed strong concern over the undermining of the trust and confidence of Internet users globally due to recent revelations of pervasive monitoring and surveillance" and "called for accelerating the globalization of ICANN and IANA functions, towards an environment in which all stakeholders, including all governments, participate on an equal footing". This desire to reduce United States association with the internet is considered a reaction to the ongoing [[PRISM (surveillance program)|NSA surveillance scandal]]. The statement was signed by the managers of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN), the [[Internet Engineering Task Force]], the [[Internet Architecture Board]], the [[World Wide Web Consortium]], the [[Internet Society]], and the five [[Regional Internet Registries|regional Internet address registries]] ([[African Network Information Center]], [[American Registry for Internet Numbers]], [[Asia-Pacific Network Information Centre]], [[Latin America and Caribbean Internet Addresses Registry]], and [[Réseaux IP Européens Network Coordination Centre]]).[http://www.icann.org/en/news/announcements/announcement-07oct13-en.htm Montevideo Statement on the Future of Internet Cooperation], ICANN, October 7, 2013. Retrieved October 12, 2013.[https://www.theregister.co.uk/2013/10/11/internet_heavyweights_turn_backs_on_snoopy_us_demand_global_oversight/ "Brazil's anti-NSA prez urged to SNATCH keys to the internet from America"], Rik Myslewski, ''The Register'', October 11, 2013. Retrieved October 11, 2013.{{cite news | url=http://www.internetgovernance.org/2013/11/19/booting-up-brazil/ | title=Booting up Brazil | work=IGP Blog | author=Milton Mueller | date=November 19, 2013 | accessdate=February 11, 2014 }} ===Global Multistakeholder Meeting on the Future of Internet Governance (2013)=== During October 2013, Fadi Chehadé, current President and CEO of ICANN, met with Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff in Brasilia. Upon Chehadé's invitation, the two announced that Brazil would host an international summit on Internet governance during April 2014.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nJmFAMJNx94 "Entrevista com Fadi Chehadé: Brasil sediará encontro mundial de governança da internet em 2014"], Palácio do Planalto, October 9, 2013. Retrieved March 4, 2014. The announcement came after the [[2013 global surveillance disclosures|2013 disclosures of mass surveillance]] by the U.S. government, and President Rousseff's speech at the opening session of the 2013 United Nations General Assembly, where she strongly criticized the American surveillance program as a "breach of international law". The "[[Global Multistakeholder Meeting on the Future of Internet Governance]] (NET mundial)" will include representatives of government, industry, civil society, and academia.[http://rt.com/news/brazil-internet-summit-fight-nsa-006/ "Brazil to host global internet summit in ongoing fight against NSA surveillance"], RT News, October 10, 2013. Retrieved November 5, 2013. At the [[Internet Governance Forum#IGF VIII — Bali, Indonesia 2013|IGF VIII meeting in Bali in October 2013]] a commenter noted that Brazil intends the meeting to be a "[[Summit (meeting)|summit]]" in the sense that it will be high level with decision-making authority.[http://www.intgovforum.org/cms/Chair%27s%20Summary%20IGF%202013%20Final.Nov1v1.pdf "Chair's Summary"], Eighth Meeting of the Internet Governance Forum (IGF), Bali, Indonesia, October 22–25, 2013. Retrieved November 5, 2013. The organizers of the "NET mundial" meeting have decided that an online forum called "/1net", set up by the I* group, will be a major conduit of non-governmental input into the three committees preparing for the meeting in April.{{cite news | url=http://www.circleid.com/posts/20140127_centr_internet_governance_in_2013_and_whats_coming_up_in_2014/ | title=CENTR: Internet Governance in 2013 and What's Coming Up in 2014 | work=CircleID | date=January 27, 2014 | accessdate=February 11, 2014 }} {{cite news | url=http://www.circleid.com/posts/2013112_what_is_1net_to_me/ | title=What Is "1net" to Me | work=CircleID blog | author=Paul Wilson | date=November 29, 2013 | accessdate=February 11, 2014 }} The [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama administration]] that had joined critics of ICANN during 2011{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/28/AR2011022803719.html|title=Obama administration joins critics of U.S. nonprofit group that oversees Internet|last1=Shapira|first1=Ian|date=March 1, 2011|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=September 20, 2014}} announced in March 2014 that they intended to transition away from oversight of the IANA functions contract. The current contract that the [[Commerce Department|United States Department of Commerce]] has with ICANN expired in 2015, in its place the NTIA will transition oversight of the IANA functions to the 'global multistakeholder community'.{{cite web|title=NTIA Announces Intent to Transition Key Internet Domain Name Functions|url=http://www.ntia.doc.gov/press-release/2014/ntia-announces-intent-transition-key-internet-domain-name-functions|website=NTIA|publisher=NTIA|accessdate=October 25, 2014}} ===NetMundial Initiative (2014)=== The [[NetMundial Initiative]] is a plan for international governance of the Internet that was first proposed at the Global Multistakeholder Meeting on the Future of Internet Governance (GMMFIG) conference (April 23–24, 2014) {{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-27108869 | title=Future of the internet debated at NetMundial in Brazil |work=''BBC News''| date=April 23, 2014 | accessdate=June 2, 2014 }} {{cite news | url=http://www.circleid.com/posts/20140504_netmundial_multistakeholder_statement_concludes_act_one_of_2014/ | title=NETmundial Multistakeholder Statement Concludes Act One of 2014 Internet Governance Trifecta | work=CircleID | date=May 3, 2014 | accessdate=June 2, 2014 }}{{cite news | url=http://pctechmag.com/2014/05/icann-releases-roadmap-timeline-for-future-management-of-internet/ | title=ICANN Releases Roadmap, Timeline for Future Management of Internet | work=PC Tech Magazine | date=May 21, 2014 | accessdate=June 2, 2014 }} and later developed into the NetMundial Initiative by ICANN CEO [[Fadi Chehadé]] along with representatives of the [[World Economic Forum]] (WEF) {{Cite web |url = https://agenda.weforum.org/topic/global-issues/future-of-the-internet/internet-governance-geo-politics/ |title = NETmundial Initiative – Debrief with Founding Partners |accessdate = June 2, 2014 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150209062622/https://agenda.weforum.org/topic/global-issues/future-of-the-internet/internet-governance-geo-politics/ |archivedate = February 9, 2015 |df = }} and the Brazilian Internet Steering Committee (Comitê Gestor da Internet no Brasil), commonly referred to as "CGI.br". {{cite web | url = http://cgi.br/noticia/public-declaration-on-the-netmundial-initiative-issued-by-members-of-the-board-of-cgi-br/ | title = Public Declaration on the NETmundial Initiative issued by members of the board of CGI.br | accessdate=June 2, 2014 }} The meeting produced a nonbinding statement in favor of consensus-based decision-making. It represented a compromise and did not harshly condemn mass surveillance or include the words "net neutrality", despite initial endorsement for that from Brazil. The final resolution says ICANN should be controlled internationally by September 2015. {{cite news | url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2014-04-30/at-netmundial-the-u-dot-s-dot-kept-its-companies-on-the-global-stage | title=At NETmundial, the U.S. Kept Its Companies on the Global Stage | work=Bloomberg BusinessWeek | date=April 30, 2014 | accessdate=June 2, 2014 }} A minority of governments, including Russia, China, Iran and India, were unhappy with the final resolution and wanted multilateral management for the Internet, rather than broader multistakeholder management.{{cite news | url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/opinion/the-future-of-the-internet-114050300990_1.html | title=The future of the internet | work=Business Standard | date=May 3, 2014 | accessdate=June 2, 2014 }} A month later, the Panel on Global Internet Cooperation and Governance Mechanisms (convened by the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) and the [[World Economic Forum]] (WEF) with assistance from [[The Annenberg Foundation]]), endorsed and included the NetMundial statement in its own report.{{cite web |url = http://internetgovernancepanel.org/panel-report |title = Towards a Collaborative, Decentralized Internet Governance Ecosystem – report by the Panel on Global Internet Cooperation and Governance Mechanisms |date = May 20, 2014 |accessdate = June 2, 2014 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140606202714/http://internetgovernancepanel.org/panel-report |archivedate = June 6, 2014 |df = }} During June 2014, France strongly attacked ICANN, saying ICANN is not a fit venue for Internet governance and that alternatives should be sought.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/france-attacks-icann-unfit-internet-governance-233956870.html|title=France attacks ICANN as unfit for internet governance|date=June 25, 2014|publisher=[[Yahoo! News]]|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|accessdate=September 20, 2014}} ===.sucks domain=== ICANN has received more than $60 million from gTLD auctions,{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2015/04/17/icann_gltd_auction_money/|title=ICANN banked $60m from dot-word auctions. Just what exactly is it going to spend it all on?|work=The Register|date=April 17, 2015}} and has accepted the controversial domain name ".sucks" (referring to the primarily US slang for being inferior or objectionable).{{cite web |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2015/04/10/icann_ftc_dot_sucks/|title=ICANN urges US, Canada: Help us stop the 'predatory' monster we created ... dot-sucks!|work=The Register|date=April 10, 2015}} .sucks domains are owned and controlled by the Vox Populi Registry which won the rights for .sucks gTLD in November 2014.{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2015/05/20/dot-sucks-web-address|title=Dot Sucks Web Address|accessdate=2018-11-01}} ====Controversy==== The [[.sucks (registry)|.sucks domain registrar]] has been described as "predatory, exploitive and coercive" by the Intellectual Property Constituency that advises the ICANN board. When the .sucks registry announced their pricing model, "most brand owners were upset and felt like they were being penalized by having to pay more to protect their brands."{{cite web|url=http://www.circleid.com/posts/20150625_is_sucks_pricing_model_gaining_traction_with_other_registries/|title=Is .SUCKS Pricing Model Gaining Traction With Other Registries?|date=June 25, 2015|work=CircleID}} Because of the low utility of the ".sucks" domain, most fees come from "Brand Protection" customers registering their trademarks to prevent domains being registered.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/shortcuts/2015/mar/23/why-you-should-buy-your-dot-sucks-domain-name|title=Why You Should Buy Your Dot Sucks Domain Name|accessdate=2018-11-01}} Canadian brands had complained that they were being charged "exorbitant" prices to register their trademarks as premium names. FTC chair Edith Ramirez has written to ICANN to say the agency will take action against the .sucks owner if "we have reason to believe an entity has engaged in deceptive or unfair practices in violation of Section 5 of the FTC Act".{{cite web|url=http://www.ipprotheinternet.com/ipprotheinternetnews/article.php?article_id=4446|title=Canada weighs in on .sucks debate|date=June 19, 2015|work=IP Pro}} The Register reported that intellectual property lawyers are infuriated that "the dot-sucks registry was charging trademark holders $2,500 for .sucks domains and everyone else $10."{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2015/06/15/canada_to_icann_take_off_you_hoser/|title=Canada to ICANN in dot-sucks dot-rumble: Take off, you hoser!|work=The Register|date=June 15, 2015}} U.S. Representative [[Bob Goodlatte]] has said that trademark holders are "being shaken down" by the registry's fees.{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2015/05/19/new-domain-sparks-icann-debate/|title=A Debate Over the Domain ‘.sucks’|work=Wall Stree Journal|date=May 19, 2015}} [[Jay Rockefeller]] says that .sucks is a "a predatory shakedown scheme" and "Approving '.sucks', a gTLD with little or no public interest value, will have the effect of undermining the credibility ICANN has slowly been building with skeptical stakeholders." ===.islam and .halal domains=== On July 30, 2018, [[whistleblower]] and writer for [[the Register]] Kieran McCarthy exposed the systematic refusal of ICANN to create the .islam and .halal gTLDs through the willful breaking of the organization's own bylaws. McCarthy coined the 6-year refusal as "the internet's very own [[Trump travel ban|Muslim ban]]" after ICANN [[kowtow|kowtowed]] to Middle Eastern governments by not approving the domain name additions.{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2018/07/30/icann_muslim_ban/|title=The internet's very own Muslim ban continues: DNS overlord insists it can freeze dot-words}} ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=27em}} * [[Alternative DNS root]] * [[Domain name scams]] * [[Domain Name System]] ** [[Domain name]] ** [[Domain name registrar]] ** [[Internationalized domain name]] ** [[Top-level domain]] *** [[Country code top-level domain]] *** [[Generic top-level domain]] *** [[GeoTLD|Geographic top-level domain]] (GeoTLD) * [[IEEE Registration Authority]] * [[Internet Assigned Numbers Authority]] (IANA) * [[InterNIC]] * [[List of ICANN meetings]] * [[Montevideo Statement on the Future of Internet Cooperation]] * [[NetMundial Initiative]], a plan for governance of the Internet * [[Network Solutions]] * [[OneWebDay]] * [[OpenNIC]] * [[Trademark Clearinghouse]] * [[Uniform Domain-Name Dispute-Resolution Policy]] * [[WHOIS]] {{div col end}} == References == {{Reflist |refs = {{cite news |title = Bush administration annexes Internet |date = July 1, 2005 |work = The Register |url = https://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/07/01/bush_net_policy/ }} {{cite web |url= http://par.icann.org/ |title = 32nd International Public ICANN Meeting |date = June 22, 2008 |publisher = ICANN }} [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-13835997 ICANN increases web domain suffixes,] ''[[BBC News]]'', June 20, 2011. [Retrieved 2009-09-18]. Summit to Focus on Internet |date = December 5, 2003 |work = The Washington Post |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/ac2/wp-dyn/A36852-2003Dec4?language=printer }} {{cite web |url = http://www.ntia.doc.gov/comments/2008/ICANN_080730.html |date = July 30, 2008 |title = U.S. DoC letter to ICANN's Chairman |accessdate = August 3, 2008 }} {{cite news |title = United States cedes control of the Internet – but what now? |date = July 27, 2006 |work = The Register |url = https://www.theregister.co.uk/2006/07/27/ntia_icann_meeting/ }} Hannibal Travis, The Battle for Mindshare: the Emerging Consensus that the First Amendment Protects Corporate Criticism and Parody on the Internet, 10 Virginia Journal of Law and Technology 3, 32–34 (2005), [http://www.vjolt.net/vol10/issue1/v10i1_a3-Travis.pdf Vjolt.net] [http://www.voanews.com/english/news/science-technology/New-Internet-Name-Rule-Opens-Door-to-Huge-Changes-124180874.html New Internet Name Rule Opens Door to Huge Changes.] [[Voice of America]], June 20, 2011. Retrieved June 20, 2011. {{cite web |url = http://www.iab.org/documents/correspondence/2003-10-17-crocker-wildcards.html |title = Wildcard entries in DNS entries |date = October 17, 2003 |author = Geoff Huston |publisher = [[Internet Architecture Board|IAB]] |accessdate = June 23, 2008 }} [https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110620/ap_on_hi_te/as_internet_domain_names;_ylt=Arq2MV_LZjTuVPrs9JafjPJ34T0D;_ylu=X3oDMTJ0OGxxanN2BGFzc2V0A2FwLzIwMTEwNjIwL2FzX2ludGVybmV0X2RvbWFpbl9uYW1lcwRwb3MDNQRzZWMDeW5fYXJ0aWNsZV9zdW1tYXJ5X2xpc3QEc2xrA2ludGVybmV0bWluZA-- Internet minders OK vast expansion of domain names,] [[Associated Press]], June 20, 2011. Retrieved June 20, 2011. [http://www.zdnet.co.uk/news/networking/2011/06/20/icann-to-allow-any-word-as-a-domain-40093152/ Icann to allow any word as a domain,] [[ZDNet]], June 20, 2011. Retrieved June 20, 2011. }} ==Further reading== * Brito, Jerry. "[http://techland.time.com/2011/03/05/icann-vs-the-world/ ICANN vs. the World]." ''[[TIME (magazine)|TIME]]''. March 5, 2011. Retrieved March 6, 2011. * Franda, Marcus, ''The Emergence of an International Regime'', {{ISBN|1-55587-999-3}} * Wass, Erica, ''Addressing the World'', {{ISBN|0-7425-2809-X}} * Paré, Daniel J. ''Internet Governance in Transition'', {{ISBN|0-7425-1846-9}} * Mueller, Milton L. ''Ruling the Root'', {{ISBN|0-262-13412-8}} * Froomkin, A. Michael [http://personal.law.miami.edu/~froomkin/articles/icann.pdf Wrong Turn in Cyberspace: Using ICANN to Route Around the APA and the Constitution], 50 Duke Law Journal17 (2000) == External links == {{Commons category|ICANN}} * {{Official website|//www.icann.org/}} * [http://dns.icann.org/ ICANN DNS Operations] * {{cite web |url = https://www.icannwiki.org |title = ICANN Wiki |publisher = ICANN |quote = People and companies related to ICANN }} * {{cite news |url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/video/2014/feb/28/who-holds-seven-keys-internet-web-security-video |work= Technology |title= Who holds the seven keys to the internet? |format= video |date= February 28, 2014 |first1= James |last1= Ball |first2= Laurence |last2= Mathieu-Leger }} {{-}} {{ICANN structure}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Icann}} [[Category:Domain name system]] [[Category:History of the Internet]] [[Category:Information technology organizations]] [[Category:Internet governance organizations]] [[Category:Internet in the United States]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in California]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1998]] [[Category:United States Department of Commerce]] [[Category:1998 establishments in California]]

'''Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami,''' also known as ICA Miami, is a contemporary art museum located in the [[Miami Design District]] in Miami, Florida, United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.miamidesigndistrict.net/listing/415/institute-of-contemporary-art-miami/|title= Institute of Contemporary Art Miami |website=Miami Design District}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dezeen.com/2017/12/05/institute-contemporary-art-ica-miami-opens-permanent-home-metal-faced-building-aranguren-gallegos-design-district/|title= IICA Miami opens permanent home in metal-faced building by Aranguren + Gallegos |website=Dezeen}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/southflorida/news/2017/12/04/institute-of-contemporary-art-miami-museum-opens.html|title= Institute of Contemporary Art Miami museum opens in Design District (Photos) |website=Biz Journal}}</ref> The Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami is dedicated to promoting continuous experimentation in contemporary art, advancing new scholarship, and fostering the exchange of art and ideas throughout the Miami region and internationally.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.icamiami.org/about/|title=About the Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|work=Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en-US}}</ref> Through a calendar of exhibitions and programs, and its collection, ICA Miami provides an international platform for the work of local, emerging, and under-recognized artists, and further advances the public appreciation and understanding of the most innovative art of our time. The museum is deeply committed to providing open, public access to art by offering year-round free admission.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.icamiami.org/visit/|title=Visit {{!}} Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|work=Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
==History==
Institute of Contemporary Art first opened in 1996 under the ''Museum of Contemporary art'' in a building designed by [[Charles Gwathmey]]. In 2014, due to issues of zoning, the museum’s board sued the city for the right to move, leading to the establishment of the Institute of Contemporary Art in 2017 in the current Design District location.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wmagazine.com/story/institute-of-contemporary-art-miami-museum-highlights |title= Inside the Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami's Newest Museum |website=W Magazine}}</ref> The [[Museum of Contemporary Art, North Miami]] remains at the old location.
== Architecture == [[File:ICA Miami 17-11 2839 03.jpg|thumb|ICA Miami: view from the front]] Funded by Norman Braman and his wife, who remains co-chair on the board of trustees at ICA, the architectural design of the museum’s building is an integral part of the museum’s reputation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/11/arts/design/in-miami-the-bramans-plan-the-institute-of-contemporary-art.html|title=Envisioning a Museum, the Sky’s the Limit|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en}}</ref> Designed in 2017 by Aranguren & Gallegos architects, the building was constructed to mimic a “Magic Box” with its bright and geometrically shape and texture.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.archdaily.com/889152/ica-miami-museum-aranguren-and-gallegos-arquitectos|title=ICA Miami Museum / Aranguren&Gallegos Arquitectos|date=2018-02-18|work=ArchDaily|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en-US}}</ref> The building consists of 37,500-square-feet of space, including its exterior.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.surfacemag.com/articles/institute-contemporary-art-miami-gets-new-home/|title=The Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami, Gets a New Home|website=Surface Magazine}}</ref> Three stories tall, with 20,000 feet of gallery space to house the various exhibitions and permanent collection, as well as a sculpture garden in the back, the structure borders the residential neighbourhood adjacent to the Design District.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.culturedmag.com/ica-miami/|title=ICA Miami Makes its Much Anticipated Debut with The Everywhere Studio|date=2017-11-27|work=Cultured Magazine|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en-US}}</ref> The back side of the structure is lined with windows to keep sunshine coming through the building, and to give any visitors a chance to see the sculpture garden that lies below the rows of windows. The 15,000 foot sculpture garden is home to works by [[Mark Handforth]], [[Abigail DeVille]], [[Allora & Calzadilla|Allora and Calzadilla]], and [[Pedro Reyes (artist)|Pedro Reyes]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.culturedmag.com/ica-miami/|title=ICA Miami Makes its Much Anticipated Debut with The Everywhere Studio|date=2017-11-27|work=Cultured Magazine|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en-US}}</ref> The building was visualised as a sort of magnet, both literally and figuratively. Not only was the concept of attracting the public with a geometrical design important to the concept, but the facade of the building itself can be compared to the dark grey and smooth material of any magnet.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dezeen.com/2017/12/05/institute-contemporary-art-ica-miami-opens-permanent-home-metal-faced-building-aranguren-gallegos-design-district/|title=ICA Miami opens permanent home in metal-faced building|date=2017-12-05|work=Dezeen|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Permanent Collection == As is true for much of the museum’s art, Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami’s permanent collection seeks to reflect efforts to expose new talent, while also showcasing many well known artists.<sup>[10]</sup> The collection include works from many different artists including [[Rita Ackermann|Rita Ackerman]], [[Francis Alÿs]], [[Hernan Bas]], [[Louise Bourgeois]], [[William Copley (artist)|William Copley]], Ann Craven, [[José Antonio Hernández-Díez|Jose Antonio Hernandez Diez]], [[Inka Essenhigh]], [[Mark Handforth]], [[Jim Hodges (artist)|Jim Hodges]], [[Edward Kienholz|Nancy and Edward Kienholz]], [[Guillermo Kuitca]], [[Zoe Leonard]], [[John Miller (American artist)|John Miller]], [[Malcolm Morley|Malcom Morley]], [[Chris Ofili]], [[Gabriel Orozco]], Enoc Perez, [[Raymond Pettibon]], Robert Therrien, and [[James Turrell]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icamiami.org/collection/page/5/|title=Collection Archive {{!}} Page 5 of 10 {{!}} Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|website=Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref>
== Exhibitions == With its opening in December 2017, Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami provided another exhibition platform for Miami Art Basel, a critically acclaimed cultural attraction to the city.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.artbasel.com/news/alex-gartenfeld-ica-miami|title=ICA Miami’s Alex Gartenfeld: ‘This is a museum that refuses to be an artistic temple’ {{!}} Art Basel|last=Basel|first=Art|website=Art Basel|language=en|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> Various artists had work shown at the opening, such as [[Abigail DeVille|Abigail DeVille’]]<nowiki/>s work in the sculpture garden, Tomm el-Saieh, [[Senga Nengudi]], [[Edward Kienholz|Edward and Nancy Kienholz]], and [[Hélio Oiticica]]. Furthermore, ICA introduced “The Everywhere Studio.” The exhibition, which was curated by Alex Gartenfield, director of the museum, Gean Moreno, program curator for the museum, and Stephanie Siedel.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.widewalls.ch/ica-miami-the-everywhere-studio/|title=Time In Our Hands: ICA Miami's The Everywhere Studio|work=Widewalls|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> The Everywhere studio was considered to be the most notable portion of the museum’s opening.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wmagazine.com/story/institute-of-contemporary-art-miami-museum-highlights|title=Inside the Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami's Newest Museum|last=Lubow|first=Arthur|work=W Magazine|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en}}</ref> It showcased more than 100 works from more than fifty artists spanning over the past five decades. The exhibition became known for its mixing of well known and unknown artists and wide variety of time and location explored. [[Pablo Picasso]] and [[Roy Lichtenstein]], both well-known artist from the mid 20th century, were showcased amongst far lesser known Miami artists.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://resnicow.com/client-news/ica-miami-unveils-inaugural-program-its-new-permanent-home-opening-december-1-2017|title=ICA Miami Unveils Inaugural Program of its New Permanent Home, Opening December 1, 2017|date=2017-06-29|work=R+A|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.widewalls.ch/ica-miami-the-everywhere-studio/|title=Time In Our Hands: ICA Miami's The Everywhere Studio|work=Widewalls|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref>
Since its opening exhibitions, the museum has housed many different exhibitions. In April 2018, [[Donald Judd]] was represented in “Donald Judd: Paintings,” an exhibition that showcased 14 of Judd’s paintings from the years 1959 to 1961. Within the same month, exhibitions by [[Walter Darby Bannard]] and [[Francis Alÿs]] opened to the public. Later, in May of 2018, ICA Miami focused on [[Diamond Stingily]] in the artist’s first solo show, “Diamond Stingily: Life In My Pocket.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.icamiami.org/exhibitions/|title=Exhibitions {{!}} Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|work=Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en-US}}</ref> The multi-media exhibition drew large crowds at its opening.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.miamitodaynews.com/2018/06/19/new-institute-of-contemporary-art-leaders-hail-attendance/|title=New Institute of Contemporary Art Leaders hail attendance - Miami Today|website=www.miamitodaynews.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> Simultaneously, an exhibit of [[Terry Adkins|Terry Adkins’]] work opened in one of the museum’s exhibition spaces. “Terry Adkins: Infinity Is Always Less Than One” comprised more than 50 works from throughout the artist’s life.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.miaminewtimes.com/arts/terry-adkins-posthumous-exhibit-at-ica-miami-may-17-10339183|title=ICA Miami Mounts First Posthumous Terry Adkins Show|last=Vazquez|first=Neil|date=2018-05-11|work=Miami New Times|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> In July of 2018, [[Sondra Perry]]’s exhibition, “Sondra Perry: Typhoon Coming On,” was opened to the public. Perry’s exhibition used multiple forms of media to “explore the intersection of black identity, digital culture and power.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.artrabbit.com/events/sondra-perry-typhoon-coming-on-ica-miami|title=Sondra Perry: Typhoon coming on - Exhibition at ICA Miami in Miami|website=ArtRabbit|language=en|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> Also opened in July of 2018, ICA Miami created a space for works by [[Louise Bourgeois]]. With one of the artist’s works already in the museum’s permanent collection, the exhibition focuses on Bourgeois’ other notable sculptures. In early November 2018, ICA Miami curated Manuel Solano’s exhibition, “Manuel Solano:I Don’t Wanna Wait For Our Lives To Be Over.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.icamiami.org/exhibitions/|title=Exhibitions {{!}} Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|work=Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en-US}}</ref> “Larry Bell: Time Machine,” also opened in November, surveys many of [[Larry Bell (artist)|Larry Bell]]’s various works, from his early works to the glass sculptures and works he is generally known for.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://resnicow.com/client-news/major-solo-exhibitions-judy-chicago-and-larry-bell-culminate-2018-season-institute|title=Major Solo Exhibitions of Judy Chicago and Larry Bell to Culminate 2018 Season at the Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|date=2018-06-21|work=R+A|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en}}</ref>
== Programs == Apart from the free access provided to acclaimed exhibitions across various artistic platforms, the Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami is also known for the various programs and services it provides. ICA Ideas build upon the current exhibitions available to the public with different classes and speeches, and providing a platform for additional performances. Through this program, for example, [[Charles Gaines (artist)|Charles Gaines]] composed a performance for the museum’s crowd entitled ''A Visual Recital.''<ref>{{Citation|title=IDEA 009: Charles Gaines Performance {{!}} Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|url=https://www.icamiami.org/program/idea-009-charles-gaines-performance/|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> ICA Speaks is one of the museum’s programs that invites associated artists to give speeches or organise symposiums regarding the various permanent works displayed in the space. Panels and speeches from artists such as [[Mark Handforth]] and [[Hernan Bas]] have been arranged for purposes of explanation and audience engagement.<ref>{{Citation|title=ICA Speaks: Mark Handforth {{!}} Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|url=https://www.icamiami.org/program/ica-speaks-mark-handforth/|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> ICA Performs consists of various dance, theatre, and other performing art programs that put on showcases in various parts of the museum. The museum has collaborated with performance artists such as Michael Clark and [[Trisha Brown]] to provide museum-goers with live performances.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.icamiami.org/program/ica-performs-trisha-brown-dance-company/|title=Trisha Brown: In Plain Site {{!}} Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|work=Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en-US}}</ref> Lastly, ICA Residents is an inaugural program that was dedicated to exposure of local musicians. The various events were in partnership with Miami Music Club, and they were centred around the idea of pairing local Miami artists with non-local artists in a singular showcase. The headliners were artists such as [[Drew McDowall]], Via App and Profligate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icamiami.org|title=ICA Miami: Free Admission Every Day!|website=Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref>
== Management == Overseeing the construction of the current permanent venue, Ellen Salpenter joined as director of the museum in December 2015. In early 2018, Ellen Salpenter, director of ICA Miami since 2015, stepped down. Taking Salpenter's place, Alex Gartenfield, the deputy director and chief curator, became artistic director in 2018, with Tommy Ralph Pace taking on the role of deputy director.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/2018/04/12/ellen-salpeter-steps-director-ica-miami/|title=Ellen Salpeter Steps Down as Director of ICA Miami|last=Battaglia|first=Andy|date=2018-04-12|website=ARTnews|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> Gartenfield is also known for his work at the New Museum, where he is co-curator.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/02/arts/design/new-museum-triennial.html|title=Meet Six Disrupters at the New Museum’s Triennial|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Contemporary art galleries]] [[Category:Art museums established in 2017]] [[Category:Art museums in Florida]] [[Category:Museums in Miami]]
